While its likely that there will not be the same level of support that was offered before, it will none-the-less help Mongolia.

The tumultuous events that have rocked the socialist camp in Europe and the USSR have not spared Mongolia. Already opposition forces have monopolized on growing unrest and instability  forming new organizations and movements across the country. While up until this point the party has acted with increasing transparency and leniency to dissent  it seems even those reforms have not been enough. Hoping to preserve socialism in Mongolia however, many of the more reformist leaning party members have suggested making concessions to the opposition within the framework of socialism, preserving the Mongolian People's Republic while adapting its institutions to a changing world.

Long having been a vocal voice and active proponent in securing Mongolia's place within CMEA, and from there furthering its ties to its European allies, Luvsantserengiin Tsend now hopes to increase that relationship even further with increased trade to Europe. While Mongolia have done well with its modernization and economic development, there is still much work to be done  and it is the hopes of those that support the move that by increasing Mongolia's exports and moving away by a reliance on Soviet and Chinese inputs that the country can hasten those final steps.

Chairman Luvsantserengiin Tsend today has passed, leaving Mongolia to mourn the passing of a loyal servant of the people while those in the party scramble to find a replacement. Already two notable candidates have risen above the rest to vie for the spot  Batmonkh, a former professor and reformist, as well as Tomor-Ochir who has been increasingly vocal about his nationalist views.
Chinese Development Aid
This nation is receiving economic assistance from China in the form of manpower and resources, helping to boost output and efficiency.

The 'Khost disturbances', or more widely known as the 'Afghan Tribal Revolts', were a series of revolts by the Zadran, Safi, and Mangal tribesmen in the southeastern sections of the Kingdom of Afghanistan that took place from 1944 to 1947. The most prevalent causes of the unrest was opposition to the policies of the Afghan government at the time as well as the worsening conditions - with poverty having grown in recent years. \n\n While a bulk of the fighting had taken place in the early days of the revolts, which themselves were largely unsuccessful and relegated to the border between the - at the time - British Raj and Afghanistan, they would shake the Afghan state and pave the way for future unrest in the region. Sporadic unrest and fighting would continue for years after, with the Afghan government eventually taking a more hands off approach to the areas to avoid provoking further action.

Since the declaration of the 'Durand Line' by the British in 1863, the Pashtun people have been forced to accept a political reality of subjugation and division. The 'Line' set the borders between Afghanistan and what would later be part of the British Raj before decolonization - settling issues on the limits of the British spheres of influence in Central Asia. This decision, seemingly, would completely shelf the idea of a united Pashtun state indefinitely, with attempts to reunite the peoples being wholly unsuccessful and serving only to further entrench the British influence. \n\n However, with recent events in the world it seems the hope of a united 'Pashtunistan' has seemingly been born anew. The Pashtun peoples of the North-West Frontier Province have made a formal declaration - which they are calling the 'Bannu Resolution' - in which they express their desire to for independence from the British Raj entirely, rather than remaining part of either India or Pakistan. Many more within that same movement hope for unification with Afghanistan, drawing the attention of many that hold more nationalist leanings within the Kingdom who hope that with a declaration of support and what little pressure they are able to exert on the British that a simple demand could become a reality.

The 'Durand Line', created in 1863 to officially settle matters of British influence in Central Asia, has long stood as the final borders between the Afghan Kingdom and British India. While contentious, having divided the Pashtun people, it has remained in place since its creation with little alteration aside from additional treaties with the bordering Afghan state - owing to a swift response to various revolts and risings against its imposition as well as agreement and cooperation from the Afghan government. \n\n However, with plans for an independent India and Pakistan slowly coming to fruition, many in the North-West Frontier Province have begun to voice a more open dissatisfaction with the options presented to them by the authorities within the Raj. Rather than having the open choice of joining either Pakistan or India, instead they have issued a resolution calling for options for complete Independence, and even a union with Afghanistan, be added to any potential referendum in the region.

In a surprising turn of events, the United Kingdom has agreed to allow the Pashtun people within British India the chance at self-determination and independence. While a far cry from the full extent that the nationalists within Afghanistan want, it is set to be the first step in the road to reuniting Pashtunistan under a single state once more.

Despite support from both the Pashtun community within British India and from the Afghan government, the British have declined the demands set forth in the Bannu Resolution. Instead, they have decided to go forward with holding their already planned referendum, ensuring that the territories will be part of the future state of Pakistan.

The Democratic Women's Organization of Afghanistan, or DOWA, was a women's advocacy group founded in the capital city of Kabul by various prominent Afghan women. Initially somewhat independent, it quickly aligned itself with the various communist organizations in the country and took an extremely active political role - working against traditionalism and organizing action against attempts to curtail gender equality within the country.

The 1964 constitution, while not fully enacted by the King, brought a new era to the politics of the Kingdom of Afghanistan. While voter turnout would remain low during the first few elections, as more and more of the populace - especially in more urban and developed areas - became involved in politics the numbers would eventually swell. Even still, conservatives remained a dominant political force, in part due to lingering political restrictions, as well as corruption. \n\n The 1965 elections were themselves dominated by the more urban sectors of the population - especially in and around Kabul. This factor, combined with low voter turnout, would allow more progressive minded elements to gain power within the parliament, though even still conservatives remained a powerful force and the King's interference would remain present.

While promises of democracy and increased freedom had flowed from the elites of Kabul, very little became a political reality. Voter turnout in the country remained low, interference from the Monarch remained, and political parties faced difficulties in promoting candidates. \n\n Speaking out against what they saw as a corrupt, repressive regime and goaded on by both political organizations within and outside of the government, including prominent leftist organizations, Student protests broke out following the 1965 elections - aiming to occupy the legislature and frustrate its operations until their demands were fulfilled. While initially these protests were met with a cautious muted response from the government, as they dragged on more and more of a response was demanded from police and military. The growing tension eventually escalated into a confrontation that left at least 3 dead, putting an end to the protests while only serving to fan the flames of anti-government sentiments among the population.

The 1964 constitution, while not fully enacted by the King, brought a new era to the politics of the Kingdom of Afghanistan. While voter turnout would remain low during the first few elections, as more and more of the populace - especially in more urban and developed areas - became involved in politics the numbers would eventually swell. Even still, conservatives remained a dominant political force, in part due to lingering political restrictions, as well as corruption. \n\n The 1969 elections were marked by a higher voter turnout than the last election. Doubts about the new constitution that had plagued the earlier 1965 elections had faded, with other sectors of the population joining the urban centers. Subsequently the small progressive surge seen in 1965 would be tempered as land-owners turned out to vote, electing their own candidates.

Between 1968 and 1970 the Democratic Women's Organization of Afghanistan would involve itself in the organization and execution of several protests aimed at its perceived injustices within society. Attempts by the conservative forces in the country to reverse the freedoms and rights that had been given to women in the country, including restricting foreign education, were met with mass protests while violence by more radical traditionalist elements of society that had been angered by their own grievances would result mass movements to force government action and investigation.

Disaster has struck Afghanistan as one of the worst droughts in its history ravages the nation, with the threat of wide-scale famine already gripping the more remote parts of the nation. Millions are at risk of losing their lives as the government struggles to respond to the magnitude of the drought's impact, with many more left to suffer the more long-term effects. Not only is food becoming more scarce, but rising poverty, homelessness, and interruption of services wrack the nation as the economy begins to feel the effects - with years of recovery laying ahead.

Hoping to help Afghanistan recover from its economic troubles and finally mount a government response to the severe famines that had resulted from the drought in 72, Mohammed Daoud Khan announced an ambitious 'Seven-Year Plan' set to take place from 1976 to 1983. The details of the plan itself involved heavy state spending on construction projects throughout the nation that were set to be funded by, what Daoud hoped, would be an influx of foreign aid from neighboring nations - especially those within the Muslim world.

While initially cooperative with the moderately reformist Parchamites, even receiving aid from the group in mobilizing forces for the 1973 coup, relations soon sourced between the communists and President Mohammed Daoud Khan's ruling National Revolutionary Party. Starting just a few years after its coming to power the regime would take on an openly anti-communist attitude, cracking down and arresting prominent leftist figures within the country and taking active measures to prevent dissent against the regime. These actions would, however, only serve to weaken the already shaky Republic.

Since the PDPA's creation in 1965, a massive rift within Afghanistan's communist movement has only deepened. While united together in a shared belief in socialism, the two main factions of the People's Democratic Party disagree aggressively on how to achieve it. While the 'Khalq' faction (whose name means Masses, or 'People') adhere to more orthodox Marxist-Leninist principles, the 'Parcham' faction ('Banner' or 'Flag') have maintained that Afghanistan is too underdeveloped as of yet to operate under the traditional Marxist-Leninist system - instead promoting a gradual and more democratic approach to the implementation of communism. \n\n This animosity wouldn't disappear upon the PDPA's ascent to power and the creation of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan. Instead, the Khalqists - led by Taraki - would facilitate a 'soft' purge of the Parcham faction. The move itself would be heavily influenced by the efforts of Hafizullah Amin (another prominent Khalqist politician) whose political maneuvering elevated his own position at the cost of the rival faction.

Wishing to waste little time in beginning Afghanistan's transformation from an underdeveloped nation into a socialist state, Taraki has already outlined a sweeping list of reforms, programs, projects, and campaigns aimed at accomplishing the task. Among them are large-scale literacy campaigns, land reform, the nation's first television broadcast, and several policies aimed at removing the influence of Islam from society. While the latter focus mainly on ending practices such as planned marriage, child marriage, the abolition of 'Sharia Law', and other policies deemed to be 'feudal' by the Khalqist government there is still a potential from wide-spread backlash from the more traditionalist elements of society - especially in the countryside where Islam still remains deeply rooted in culture and governance.

Amin's power-grab sent ripples of unrest and instability throughout Afghanistan, and the series of repressions and purges that followed would earn him the ire of both the Khalqists, Parchamites, and Soviets alike. In the immediate aftermath of Amin's move a group of PDPA politicians who headed various ministries, calling themselves the 'Gang of Four', began making moves to themselves oust Amin from power. However, Amin's repressions would prevent even high-ranking members of the government from being able to take effective action - leading to the four members themselves being removed from government and forcing them to flee to escape further reprisal, leaving Amin even more unchecked as he continued to try to consolidate his rule.

Taraki's more radical anti-Islamist policies, particularly his uncompromising opposition to Sharia law, would be met throughout the country with wide-spread resentment. This would be especially felt in the more underdeveloped and rural areas of the country that were still deeply rooted in the more fundamentalist aspects of Islam. Herat in particular was already the site of several smaller revolts and uprisings inspired by mullahs and landowners. However, it wasn't until the mutiny of forces sent in to deal with the more violent aspects that the unrest would turn into a full occupation of parts of the province by rebel forces. \n\n Chaos would ensue in the province and across the country as the DRA scrambled to respond to the scope of the unrest, with several being killed in Herat before forces were finally able to be sent in - causing further clashes before finally restoring government control.

Historically having been strongholds of tribal power in Afghanistan, an offensive in the south-eastern sections of the country have proved fruitful in tackling the growing opposition to socialist rule in the country. The Afghan army, along with loyal militia groups and police forces, have managed to route several rebel groups in the nation - pushing those that didn't surrender into neighboring Pakistan as they attempt to regroup.

Emboldened by the instability that happened in the wake of Amin's coup, as well as a direct reaction against it, a coalition of Maoist, moderate islamist, and anti-Soviet Marxist groups have begun an attempted insurrection in Kabul. Occupying the historical fortress of Bala Hissar, their aim is to inspire similar revolts across the nation - leading to the formation of a broad leftist government outside of the influence of the USSR and able to resist influence from neighboring regimes. Already, however, government forces have begun a swift response to their uprising, with aerial bombardment working to pave the way for ground forces.

While the intervention of the Soviet Union was primarily aimed at ousting Amin from power, it proved to only fan the flames of resentment among many portions of the population to the Democratic Republic and socialist rule. Karmal, who had risen to power in the aftermath of Amin's removal, would be seen as little more than a puppet of the Soviet Union - serving to weaken his authority over the nation and even the PDPA itself. Such sentiments would prove to lesson the effectiveness of his policies and divide the nation further, radicalizing more conservatives around the growing rebel threat.

The 'Fundamental Principles', also known as the 'Fundamental Principles of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan', refer to a series of changes to the government that were aimed at solidifying Parchamite rule, increasing civilian participation in governance, appeasing traditionalist elements of society - particularly those in active opposition to the regime through offers of amnesty, and restoring rule of law within the DRA. The Principles included securing a degree of freedom of speech and assembly, rules and rights for legal trial, elections, and some degree of economic liberalization.

Since the PDPA's creation in 1965, a massive rift within Afghanistan's communist movement has only deepened. While united together in a shared belief in socialism, the two main factions of the People's Democratic Party disagree aggressively on how to achieve it. While the 'Khalq' faction (whose name means Masses, or 'People') adhere to more orthodox Marxist-Leninist principles, the 'Parcham' faction ('Banner' or 'Flag') have maintained that Afghanistan is too underdeveloped as of yet to operate under the traditional Marxist-Leninist system - instead promoting a gradual and more democratic approach to the implementation of communism. \n\n The restoration of the Parchamite faction following the Soviet intervention against Khalqist Amin shifted the balance of power within the PDPA significantly in favor of the former and with Karmal's ascent to power provided a chance for the dynamics of the PDPA to even further change. While professing a degree of unity initially, and attempting to share power with the Khalqists, persisting animosity would lead to small scale purges of more hardliner elements from government and the continued infighting and division of the party.

The '3 Hoot uprising' - whose name comes from the Persian Calendar - refers to a series of protests, spontaneous uprisings, and student demonstrations throughout Afghanistan made in opposition to Soviet intervention in the country and the leadership of Karmal. A bulk of the interconnected protests, whose initial spark is not fully known, were organized by the Maoist Liberation Organization of the People of Afghanistan and other Moaist organizations. The extent to the dissent would result in a backlash from the government, seeing most of the protests, riots, and unrest put down with force.

Hoping to further increase participation in government and democratize Afghan society, Karmal and the Parchamites have proposed the creation of a National Front government - similar to those in other communist states. Named the 'National Fatherland Front', the National Front would serve as a coalition of parties operating within the framework of socialism and aim to give more of a voice to those that didn't wish to join or associate with the PDPA and its own inner-party institutions while still involving themselves within the politics of the DRA and working towards a shared goal of modernizing the nation. The creation of the front is set to be paired with a massive campaign to support the organization, as well as encourage more political solutions to grievances with the government.

Amid a continued insurgency and ineffective policies, Karmal has announced the establishment of a ten-point National Reconciliation program. In order to reach this end he has already selected a range of non-PDPA members to head a committee organizing the task, as well as carrying it out across the nation. The program itself will be aimed at reaching a power-sharing settlement with rebel forces, and will come along-side further attempts to democratize Afghan society and entrench rule of law.

Karmal initially enjoyed substantial support from the Soviet Union, especially at the onset of his rise to prominence following the intervention that ousted Amin from power. However, years of ineffective politics, increasing reformism within the CPSU, and an increasingly violent and prolonged insurgency has eroded the good-will and faith in Karmal from his Soviet advisors and allies. While the Afghan leader is safe for now, content to ignore calls for his resignation, his political rivals within the PDPA have already begun making their own moves for the now almost inevitable fall from power.

With Karmal's departure from power comes a struggle within the PDPA for who will take the former leader's place. The main divide, as has been the case since its foundation, is between a member of the increasingly reformist Parcham faction and the adamantly hardline Khalqists. Currently the former is represented by the pro-democracy Najibullah, who enjoys substantial support within the party and from reformists within the Soviet Union, while the latter is represented by the more moderate Abdul Qadir who served within the Afghan army and within the government as Minister of Defense.

Hoping to further solidify Afghanistan's democratic institutions, as well as attempt to put an end to the insurgency plaguing the country, Najibullah has announced a deepening of the country's policy of 'National Reconciliation' policies. Far more radical than previous attempts, however, Najibullah wishes to fully abolish the one-party rule, officialize Islam as the state religion, begin the process of decommunization of government institutions, create a new legislature, and open up dialogue with various factions of the rebel groups. \n\n While such policies are far-reaching, and opposed by more hardline elements with the PDPA, many more rally behind them as the only way to put an end to a conflict that has been raging for so long.

While adamant in keeping some aspects of planned economics, and sticking to development plans started under his predecessor, Najibullah is seemingly not content with solely increased democratization. Instead, the new leader has proposed changes to the constitution to allow the establishment of fully private firms, as well as foreign investment. In addition to this, however, he has reaffirmed the countries ties to the communist bloc, pushing for increased trade to help support the Afghan economy and gain government support via its development and growth.

The Soviet people have grown increasingly weary with the costly, and seemingly endless, war in Afghanistan. What was initially a simple mission to oust Amin and prop up more moderate voices within the PDPA has turned into a drawn-out conflict that has cost many lives and only further entrenched the very enemies we fight against. With that in mind the new Reformist leadership in the USSR had put forward a motion to end the intervention, and to start the process of withdrawing troops and funding from the regions and divert them towards more pressing concerns.

The Soviet Union, now led by hardline reformists and seeing no end in sight for the conflict in Afghanistan, has decided to begin the process of withdrawing its troops from the nation. While it has pledged to continue support for the current government it has, regretfully, expressed the growing reluctance within its borders to continue direct military intervention. \n\n While the rebel groups across the country will see with withdraw as a rallying victory, the government remains hopeful in their ability to maintain order and stability through the coming months.

With Soviet forces removed from the country, the reformist leadership of the PDPA - led by Najibullah - have increased their push for democratization. Already mentions of communism and socialism are being removed from the party platform, legal system, and government - with communist and socialist symbols to follow. This comes along-side yet more reforms to the nation's already shaken government, the almost complete opening of politics to wider society in a last attempt to resolve Afghanistan's problems through peaceful political means.

Hoping to halt Afghanistan's current path, a strange alliance has formed in order to orchestrate a coup against the Najibullah government. Centering around a former Minister of Defense and Lt. General, Shahnawaz Tanai, several dissident Khalqists have been joined by groups within the Mujahideen in order to try to put the 'radical nationalist' into power. \n\n While unsuccessful, the means in which the coup was attempted served to destabilize the regime even further. Mujahideen groups coordinated attacks alongside the attempt, dividing the remaining army forces while other officers and officials were bribed to defect or ignore the attempt - with forces within the government also rallying behind Tanai, ultimately compromising their own positions and reopening rifts within the PDPA.

With the collapse of the Soviet Union, Afghanistan has lost its most effective tool in fighting the Mujahideen - the Airforce. With fuel shortages now grounding most aircraft, strikes across the country are impossible, transport of mechanized weaponry has become much more difficult, and offensives across the country are being made unopposed - with more and more of the nation being lost with each passing week. Without a swift end to the conflict, Afghanistan's fall is almost assured.

Defections and desertions plague what little remains of the Afghan army as they put up a vain defense against the Mujahideen who now stand poised to take the capital and finally achieve their goal of overthrowing the Republic of Afghanistan. Their forces, already within striking distance, have faced little resistance as major commanders abandon their posts - taking troops with them as they turn to warlordism. The only hope remains in what few soldiers stand their ground, and the police and militia groups that has taken up arms in support of the government or fear for a future under the Mujahideen.

While the factions, organizations, groups, and people that would coalesce to form the Taliban existed prior to the collapse of the communist regime in Afghanistan - it wouldn't be until around 1994 that sect would officially come into existence in a bid to overthrow the new government in Kabul. Made up primarily of the groups that rejected the Peshawar Accords the established the transitional 'Islamic State of Afghanistan', they soon came to pose themselves as more radical adherents to Islam, espousing even more extremist and hardline rhetoric inspired by strains that had bled into the country from throughout the Muslim World.

While the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan is all but complete, splits in the movement and a reorganization of opposition forces have led to an insurrection against the hardline Islamist regime. Declaring themselves the 'Northern Alliance', several warlords, Islamist figures, former Mujahideen fighters, businessmen, and even former members of the Afghan Army have joined forces to create a rival government and re-establish a more moderate rule in Kabul. Finding support abroad, its likely that their actions will prolong Afghanistan's instability for more years to come.

While the American invasion has put into power more moderate elements of the Islamist movement, and made promises of democracy, it has not been met with the wide-spread acceptance it had anticipated. Instead, many more traditional minded portions of the population have vocally put themselves in opposition to American involvement in the nation's affairs, with many more pushed to the fringe of political life in the country or directly impacted by the bombing campaigns that preceded it.

During the initial American invasion of Afghanistan Taliban forces were driven from the country, however it did not put an end to the group in its entirety. Monopolizing off of anti-American sentiment and the unpopularity of the current regime the Taliban have announced their reorganization, launching a pamphlet campaign in various rural towns and cities in the hope to recruit more to their cause and once again drive what they see as a foreign invader out.

Following the United States invasion of Afghanistan the Northern Alliance - a disparate group of warlords pushed out of Kabul by the Taliban - were once again installed as the country's governing body. They would quickly reform a transitional government, this time acting far more quickly than before in working towards creating a new government - a task that was complicated further by the return of the still somewhat popular Monarch deposed in 1973. While this would cause the debate to ultimately be between a restoration of a constitutional monarchy or a continuation of Afghanistan as a republic - American pressure would result in the former outcome being dismissed by even the former King himself, giving rise to the later 'Islamic Republic of Afghanistan'.

Afghanistan's 2004 presidential elections marked the first in the nation following the declaration of the Islamic Republic. While mired by accusations of fraud and corruption, interventions from both the United Nations and several European countries would satisfy most of the opposition within the nation. The main candidates, elected via a two-round system, were the conservative backed independent Hamid Karzai and the more populist-leaning Yunus Qanuni and his 'New Afghanistan' party.

'Ostalgia', or 'Ostalgie' - made up from the German words 'Ost' and 'Nostalgie' - describes a phenomena in the post-communist states that encompasses a wide rage of favorable outlooks on the previous communist regimes in those nations. While taking different forms in different places, having different motivations, and being both manipulated by and viewed in different lights by various political groups and portions of the population - its effect on the mindset and culture of the nations and peoples that experience it is hard to ignore. Across much of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc the so-called 'Ostalgia' would go on to inspire voting patterns, art, culture, and even the rise of new organizations and ideologies. \n\n In Afghanistan, while more faint than in countries that had experienced far more stability under communism, feelings of nostalgia for the former rule of the PDPA (and later Watan Party) would persist - experiencing a boon following the Western intervention in the country and the restoration of some semblance of a republic. Mainly taking root among those that had faced persecution by the Taliban and former Mujahedeen as well as those that remembered better times under communism, Ostalgia in Afghanistan would see the revival and reorganization of several communist parties and groups - all with the common aim of once more trying to bring socialism and stability to the war-torn nation.

With their phase of reorganization complete, the Taliban have once again started their insurgency in earnest. Already $Year$ has been marked with increased violence against the regime, especially those in positions of authority in the government. Bombing campaigns, propaganda initiatives, and uprisings degrading the already weakened faith in the government.

Afghanistan's 2009 elections would prove a massive departure from the previous elections in 2004. Whereas previously accusations of fraud and corruption were sated with intervention from abroad, the newest elections are proving to be a series of disasters. Fraud, bribery, violence, and more are among the multiple accusations - with the results being met with skepticism from most of the nation while the government adamantly denies any wrong-doing. The two main candidates, each taking their own separate issue with the accusations, are Hamid Karzai and Abdullah Abdullah of the more centrist leaning United National Front.

Burhanuddin Rabbani today was killed at his residence amid the celebrating of his 72nd birthday party. A leading figure of the Mujahideen, he would later go on to be President of Afghanistan from the collapse of the Najibullah regime until the end of the transitional period that proclaimed the Islamic Republic. \n\n Rabbani was the victim of a suicide bombing carried out by members of the Taliban who had approached him claiming to be peace delegates from the group coming to bring him an important message from the organization's leadership. Reports say the men approached him before embracing him and detonating bombs they carried. The blast also resulted in several other fatalities, and will likely only serve to further embolden the group going forward.

The 2014 elections in Afghanistan, like those prior, would be wrought with allegations of fraud. They'd pit the vocally nationalist and anti-communist Ashraf Ghani against the centrist National Coalition's choice of Abdullah Abdullah.

The 2019 elections in Afghanistan would once again lead to a face-off between Ghani and Abdullah, with the aftermath setting the motion for a political crisis in the nation. While initially attempts to mediate between the two figures were unsuccessful, eventually a power-sharing arrangement was reached in which both retained significant power in the nation - though effectively the outright winner would retain the office of the presidency.

The President today has met with top advisors to work out the final details of a US exit from Afghanistan. While the war has been raging on for nearly 20 years, with trillions spent on it and many lives lost, the mission has become increasingly unpopular with the American public that sees the conflict as another 'endless war' that has done little to improve their lives or America's position on the world stage. \n\n Already preliminary agreements have been made with several groups in Afghanistan, notably the Taliban, to help facilitate the withdraw of those loyal to the US or its own citizens and troops - with many more assurances being made by both sides. Even still, there are those within the government, media, and corporate structures of the US that have been vocal in expressing their displeasure at the idea of an end to the conflict being floated around - a myriad of different arguments being used to try to sway an increasingly weary public back in favor of an even more prolonged American presence.

The US today has begun a large-scale withdraw from the country. Already a bulk of their forces have either retreated to the capital of Kabul or outright evacuated from the country - with many more officials, advisors, generals, soldiers, and citizens soon to follow. While the speed with which events are moving along has alarmed some within the government, many - including the United States itself - are confident that Afghanistan's armed forces with their superior numbers and equipment will be able to perform the duty of America's own soldiers in holding the line against any opportunistic move made by the Taliban.

Despite the confidence in the American-trained Afghan military, the Taliban have made several gains in the past few days - province after province falling to their forces. Even still Afghan forces have continued to try to regroup and hold the line - steadily moving further and further towards Kabul as worries spread throughout the heart of Afghanistan for the future of the Islamic Republic.

Taliban forces have amassed outside of Kabul, with heavy fighting taking place between what few forces having surrendered, deserted, or been killed and the various disparate militia bands aligned with the fundamentalist group. Already many within the city have braced for defeat, traditional dress returning, traces of western culture being erased or hidden, symbols of the old regime taken down or destroyed, and government officials fleeing the nation - further adding to the chaotic situation. The only hope that remains of what little is left of the government now seems to rest solely with the assurances of amnesty by the Taliban - eager to do little to threaten their impending victory.

The few remnants of the Afghan army and government, working together with disparate other groups, have amassed themselves north of Kabul in the Panjshir Valley. Hoping to put up a last stand against Taliban rule the group is led by many of the same figures that led the previous 'Northern Alliance', with the same goal in mind. While there is little faith that they'll be able to stand up to the Taliban, with the rest of Afghanistan having already fallen, the main threat they pose is a rallying cry for those still loyal to the old regime in the country - their more hardline officials already calling for popular uprisings across the nation.

In accordance with the constitution of the Kingdom of Afghanistan, elections are set to be held - with the predominant political forces already vying for influence. Like most elections that had taken place prior in the Kingdom of Afghanistan, the two main forces would be conservatives - finding their base among the remote regions of the nation and landowners - and the Progressives and social democratic monarchists whose base of support tended to be within urban centers, and especially the capital of Kabul.

Even several long years later the drought and famine from the start of the decade continue to send ripples through Afghan society. Millions are still in poverty, faith in the government has declined massively, attempted coups and insurrections have corroded stability, and authoritarianism and corruption run rampant. Through it all, however, Afghanistan's Kingdom has endured. Now, however, we are faced with a decision to begin to finally tackle some of the more long-standing issues. Progressive elements within the government have made the proposal for an even more radical alteration of the previous constitution - stripping more power from the king and even further enshrining democratic institutions within the country. \n\n While something so bold would surely upset the more traditionalist elements of society, unrest is bound to grow no matter the action as forces continue to gather and mobilize for change in the country.

While the King and government have, in the past, worked to temper and limit their reforms - as well as make concessions to the various tribal and underdeveloped regions of Afghanistan - in order to appease the more conservative-minded population, it was only a matter of time before the modernization efforts provoked wide-spread backlash. Opposing what they see as a trampling of tradition and foreign influence within the nation many have spoken out against more progressive elements of the government, and society - attempting to rally further support against Afghanistan's continued march to modernization, including by the use of force.

Afghanistan mourns today with the passing of its late king, Mohammed Zahir Shah. Widely considered the 'Father of the Nation', the late monarch led Afghanistan through the first steps towards modernization and democratization. He is succeeded by his son, Ahmad Shah Khan, who will take his father's place and hopefully continue the legacy left behind.

After decades of gradual change and pragmatic reform, Afghanistan has finally fully entered the modern era. With a majority of the population having embraced progressive values, the Monarch's power limited by a democratic constitution, and a functioning and thriving government in place with stable foundations we can finally move forward with the country's continued development as a shining beacon to all of Central Asia and the wider Islamic world.

Even before the attempted coup, the Republic was far from stable. Despite efforts to have combated the more radical conservative strains of Islam the threat of reaction only grew during the initial economic and political instability brought on by Daoud's seizure of power. Now with tensions having mounted and opposition having reorganized it seems that things have finally boiled over into violence - with remains of the old social order, particularly among the tribes, joining forces with other conservative elements to bring about an end to the rule of the National Revolutionary Party.

The two dominant factions of the PDPA have long been divided - split by their ideological differences, with infighting and sectarianism having served only to undermine their drive towards a socialist Afghanistan. However, today it seems they have decided to put those differences aside in another attempt to oust Daoud from power and spark the fires of revolution in Afghanistan. While currently police and military forces have dealt with the more violent uprisings, there remains a threat of a potential communist insurgency.
With rebels having stormed Kabul today, the old regime has effectively been put to an end. As such its institutions and policies are to be stripped away and replaced anew.

The results of the 'Seven-Year Plan' have finally come to fruition, with Afghanistan's weakened economy now on the upturn after a decade. Massive public spending in developing infrastructure, healthcare, industrialization, institutional modernization, and more have left millions that had been cast into poverty and left abandoned by the former Kingdom with newfound jobs and purpose in society - with the efforts also significantly helping to strengthen the still shaky stability of the Republic. With any luck, this will mark a chance in Afghanistan's fortunes.

Having overseen the stabilization of both Afghanistan's new Republic and its economy, Mohammed Daoud Khan has announced today his retirement. With his age slowly catching up to him he entrusts leadership of the Republic to his son, Tariq Daoud Khan, who will surely follow in the footsteps of his father under his nominal guidance and continue to pave the way to a more modern Afghanistan.

With growing support among the population for the communist government, what remains of the Mujahideen have been declared defeated. Their numbers declining, their operations and offensives growing more and more scarce, and their propaganda failing to an ever more progressive population it is likely that the rebel organization will not survive for much longer. Such a turn of events finally opens the door for Afghanistan's march into the future, and an end to a bloody era of its history.

With the defeat of the Mujahideen in Afghanistan, Soviets soldiers have begun to finally return to their homeland in triumph. While some forces, and military bases, will be kept in the nation to ensure further cooperation with the now stabilized regime a vast majority of the resources that had been poured into the country can now be diverted else-where.

Despite what the world has been shown thus far, Afghanistan is a rich nation with the potential to outpace even the Gulf States in its economic output. While this treasure trove of resources have gone untapped thus far, we are finally ready to enter the modern era as a developed nation. Throughout the country operations are already underway to extract resources such as coal, iron, gold, uranium, and more - mineral reserves that are estimated to far exceed most other countries' own in value.

While Taraki has served as the leader of Afghanistan faithfully and loyally for nearly a decade now - many within the PDPA feel the time has come for the aging head of government to make way for a replacement. While unified for the most part, with divisions and rifts far more minimal than before the declaration of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan, there still remains fierce disagreement on which faction should be able to nominate a successor. While the Khalqists have pointed to Gulabzoy, holding a level of influence second only to Taraki himself within the party, the Parchamites have put forward a more controversial choice, Anahita Ratebzad. Head of the People's Organization of Afghan Women, Ratebzad is held up as a prominent figure who has been involved in the politics of the nation - including political organization - since prior to the coup in 73. While a woman leader would likely be seen as an insult to many traditional members of Afghan society - Parchamites are confident that her abilities would be enough to secure the rule of the DRA within the country.

After the initial period of intense repression and declining political and civil rights, the Amin government today has announced a new policy known as the 'Fundamental Principles'. While now as liberal or robust as his remaining rivals within the PDPA, the policies within outline some degree of a return to rule of law, minor freedom of expression, amnesty for certain prisoners, and the foundations of a constitution for the young state.

While it was the Soviets that initially supported Amin's ouster, the fact remains that Afghanistan has few countries willing to provide aid and arms to combat its growing internal unrest. As such, in a pragmatic move, Amin has proposed more closely aligning with the Soviet Union and attempting to improve the now strained relations between the two nations. \n\n Though some within the PDPA's more fringe factions have suggested approaching the west for assistance instead - though in the long run this could weaken Afghanistan's autonomy all the same as well as earn it more ire from its neighbors in the region who wish to stave off American influence.

After ruling Afghanistan as its unquestioned leader for years, it has been announced that the Supreme Leader of Afghanistan has passed today. While a mourning period was declared across the country the PDPA quickly scrambled to liberalize the party institutions, political rivals already returning to the country from their positions abroad to vie for leadership. Two have risen above the rest, however. Watanjar, who participated in an attempted coup against Amin and served as member of the Khalqist government under Taraki prior to the coup and Karmal, the de facto leader of the Parcham faction and a favored of Moscow who is likely to result in an alignment of the country into the Soviet sphere.

While the position of women in the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan is equal to that of men, with traditionalist and religious laws being abolished and cultural norms being actively challenged, much of the nation's women remain oppressed under reactionary ideas. To this end, Ratebzad has begun a mass campaign throughout the nation to mobilize women throughout the country towards the goal of driving reactionary forces from the country and working to build socialism. Already hundreds of young working class folks have been swayed by the rhetoric and speeches - with many choosing to join the Afghan army outright to help liberate their sisters still in bondage.

Anahita Ratebzad, like much of her fellow Parchamites, holds the view that the material conditions within Afghanistan necessitate market reforms and a degree of political liberalization. While such reforms are likely to be heavily tempered by the Khalqists, smaller scale economic reforms as well as a solidifying of rule of law are likely to face little opposition - and will likely go a long way to legitimizing the regime.

Reactionary thought persists within Afghan society, particularly among the areas with less access to education and regions that have been affected by poverty and a lack of social services in the past. In an effort to combat these Ratebzad has proposed the implementation of a large-scale propaganda campaign that target these areas - hoping to win over the minds of the people and bring new ideas to combat the old ways that have governed the country for centuries.

Conditions within Afghanistan continue to deteriorate, with the Mujahideen continuing their insurgency and uprisings and protests occurring throughout the country. This is despite the best efforts of Anahita Ratebzad, already a controversial figure for leading a traditional Islamic society as a woman, to put the nation on the path towards socialism. Monopolizing on her perceived failures and growing unpopularity within the party many have already made their moves to push for her replacement. Two candidates from each of the dominant factions in the PDPA have emerged.  Karmal, a pro-Moscow Parchamite and reformist and Gulabzoy who leads the more fiery Khalqist faction.

The time has come to elect a new leader for the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan. The choice is likely to be between candidates put forward by one of the two dominant factions of the PDPA - a reformist Parchamite and a support of democratization and liberalization, or a hardline Khalqist that will continue to legacy of the revolution. Whatever the choice, it is likely to define Afghan politics going forward, emboldening one faction while leading to a weakening of the other.

While nominally aligned with the Khalq faction of the PDPA, Abdul Qadir - one of the leading figures in bringing about the Socialist State in Afghanistan, has announced intentions to work towards a campaign within the party aimed at unifying the disparate factions and providing some semblance of cooperation between various government branches. Many members of both factions, however, remain skeptical of any attempt at reconciliation - worried to lose influence or of ending up in a situation like the numerous before. Even still, there are those that see hope in the move - while it would be costly in the short-term, stability within the PDPA would mean more effective policies and free up resources to focus on tackling more pressing issues.

Afghanistan is a country under siege from both within and abroad. While KHAD, the state security agency of Afghanistan, can be tasked with handling the external threats - the issue of the Mujahideen and other rebel groups remains domestically. In an effort to both bolster the armed forces of Afghanistan and encourage public action against the enemies of the revolution, Qadir has announced drives to ramp up recruitment in the Armed Forces as well as to establish militia groups in major provinces to mobilize supporters of the Democratic Republic against the forces of reaction.

With a more military minded and hardline leader in charge, diplomatic and political solutions to Afghanistan's conflict have been set aside in favor of military action against the forces seeking to overthrow the Democratic Republic. However, Afghanistan's military is already stretched thin with keeping order in the country - and any operations will likely have to be relegated to a single section of the country.

Whatever the choice, it is likely to define Afghan politics going forward, emboldening one faction while leading to a weakening of the other.

While few within the PDPA want to openly admit to it, fighting off the Mujahideen - themselves being supported by foreign actors - will prove to be a losing battle if waged by Afghanistan alone. It is to that end that some have suggested asking the Soviet Union to provide military assistance. While such a move could prove unpopular - and put the country firmly under Soviet influence - it may be the only way to ensure long-term stability.

With Khalqists becoming the dominant force in the divided PDPA, the question as arisen which policy should be taken within the government in relation to its rival Parcham faction. While several more hardline elements would see little issue in continuing the marginalization of the more reformist leaning members of the party - several more voices have spoken up in favor of a more moderate approach, instead focusing on unity within the party to put an end to infighting that could hamper the implementation of policies and responses to the numerous domestic issues plaguing the nation.

Seeing a prolonged conflict in Afghanistan, one that has cost the Soviet Union lives and resources, there has begun a campaign to pressure for Gulabzoy removal from his positions of leadership within the party. Instead, the reformists in the CPSU - now leading the nation - hope that a more moderate figure might be able to work towards a political or diplomatic solution to the conflict within the embattled country. Already a candidate has come forward in the form of Najibullah, a reformist member of the Parcham faction who has outlined a policy of 'National Reconciliation' in hopes of legitimizing the government in the eyes of the rebel groups. However, not everyone in the party - or in the Soviet Union - sees a radical change as the best course. Abdul Qadir, one of the leading figures in the Saur Revolution, has also come forward as a potential - more stable - replacement. His policies would be far more moderate, in line with the already dominant Khalqists and focused instead on a continued military end to the rebellion.

Even before the Saur Revolution that brought communists to power, the PDPA was a divided party and socialism in Afghanistan a fractured movement rife with infighting. However, that is to be put to an end today. Watanjar, along with other moderates within the government, have put forward the idea of launching an internal campaign of unity within the party aimed at bringing the two disparate factions more inline with a centralized coherent ideology both can rally around and worth within.

However, Afghanistan's military is already stretched thin with keeping order in the country - and any operations will likely have to be relegated to a single section of the country.

Whatever the choice, it is likely to define Afghan politics going forward, emboldening one faction while leading to a weakening of the other.

At various times Tanai has been described as a 'radical nationalist', something that has been used against him in the past. However, with him now at the helm of Afghanistan's government, it has been turned into a tool. Hoping to foster a stronger sense of national pride and instill a more powerful civic national identity - a campaign has been started to restore certain symbols of the past, as well as to loosen restrictions on certain elements of traditionalism within the nation. While not everyone within the PDPA is onboard with these changes, many more agree that such superficial policies could legitimize the government all the same.

With Shahnawaz Tanai's coup a success, the leader and his allies have started acting quickly in planning on moves to further cement their power. The Parcham faction still holds significant power within the party, and likely are themselves already planning to make a counter move against Tanai - who is more aligned with the hardline elements of the Khalq faction. Many in Tanai's inner circle believe it would be wise to preempt any attempt to work against the new Afghan leader, removing and replacing problematic politicians within the government.

The factions of the Mujahideen that helped with Tanai's coup have come to collect the debts owed to them. As per the arrangements with the more moderate sections of the rebel movement, power-sharing agreements, policy concessions, and a détente with several other groups have been fully implemented. While its likely to cause some instability in the short-term, it much of the rebel movement laying down their arms or outright rallying behind the government could prove to be a tipping point for the conflict in Afghanistan.

The situation in the communist bloc continues to look dire, with increasing liberalization in the USSR bleeding over into the republics of the Warsaw Pact - leading to destabilization and unrest that threatens the foundations of many of the Eastern Bloc nations. Through it all Afghanistan's government has been left helpless to intervene with its still limited resources, able to do little more than maintain trade ties while they can last and navigate the changing geo-political landscape. \n\n However, there is one country that is within reach of Afghanistan's influence. The Minister of State Security has submitted a proposal to send agents from KHAD to the Mongolian People's Republic in order to help restore order and hopefully preserve socialism within the country. While such a feat strains the abilities of the state security agency, securing a communist ally in Asia would go a long way in helping to protect the revolution within our own country.

With the transitional Islamic State having been able to hold out against Taliban forces, the disorganized government has finally been able to focus on the matter of determining the future of the state. While many want to retain control over a much more centralized and fundamentalist autocracy - there are many more voices that call for the establishment of a republic modeled along Islamic principles, and importantly aligned itself with the Western powers responsible for the Mujahideen's initial rise.

After decades of bloody conflict, peace has finally returned to Afghanistan. Many throughout the nation rejoice at news of the Taliban's defeat, what little remains of the organization broken and scattered - its leadership either dead, surrendered, or arrested. The government itself has issued a statement of its victory, putting forward promises of now turning its attention towards tackling more long-standing issues in the nation, working to tackle poverty, corruption, and to continue efforts to modernize the nation.

Despite the People's Uprising in 1944 that brought an end to Bulgaria's involvement with the Axis powers and saw the rise of socialist and communist forces in the country - the nation has officially remained a Kingdom. That is set to change now, however, two years later. A referendum on the status of the Monarchy is set to be held on the anniversary of the uprising against it, with projections indicating a landslide victory on the part of those that wish to see Bulgaria move into a new future as a Republic.

The Civil War in Greece rages on, now entering into its third - and possibly final - phase. While there was a brief glimmer of hope for compromise and a peaceful transition of the country towards socialism - the former anti-fascist partisans have since found themselves struggling against the oppressive and reactionary forces of the Kingdom that seek to preserve their interests. However, they shall not fight alone. Our nation is in a position to intervene - at least indirectly - in the conflict. While it remains to be seen if such actions would turn the tide, we can be sure that an allied Greece would greatly benefit our  burgeoning socialist alliance and further the cause of world revolution.

After an abrupt bout of illness, Dimitrov has passed away today while receiving treatment in Moscow. While his time in office was brief, plans have already been made to construct a mausoleum in his honor, with other funeral arrangements and events planned in coming days. However, his unexpected passing has left the politics on the nation somewhat shaken. As the dust settles, two figures have emerged to lead Bulgaria forward. The party has elected one of them, Chervenkov - a staunchly pro-Stalinist figure - to take the position of General Secretary while the more moderate Kolarov has been elected to the post of Chair of the Council of Ministers.

Since the split between Yugoslavia and the USSR, the animosity between the two nations has only grown, boiling over into the Eastern Bloc as they are steered away from closer economic and political integration with the former. Nowhere has this been felt more than in Bulgaria, where many within the BCP hold fondness for Tito and his ideals and see Soviet influence within the nation as stifling. \n\n Given the state of affairs and Soviet influence in the nation, many - especially among the more hardline elements of the party - believe it would be wise to crack down on both these 'Titoists' within the party as well as the more radical 'Home Communists'. Already a vocal member of the movement, Traicho Kostov - described as a nationalist, has been targeted along with his allies.

With the passing of Koarov, who held the post of Chair of the Council of Ministers, Bulgaria's period of 'collective leadership' has seeming fallen apart. While such an event would result in a new Chair being elected by the National Assembly, or the Council itself, Cherenkov and his allies have started making moves to ensure the post falls to Cherenkov himself - who already occupies the position of General Secretary of the party. Such a move would give the vocal Stalinist a large amount of sway over the nation, though few within the party would see the move in a positive light - preferring to keep the posts separate as well as to stave off the influence of Stalinism in Bulgaria.

Chervenkov has come to earn himself the nickname of 'Little Stalin' within Bulgaria for his zealotry to upholding 'Stalinism'. As such, he has begun to attempt to build for himself a cult of personality in the same vein as the Soviet leader he wishes to emulate - cracking down even more on dissent and attempting to empower himself even more within the apparatuses of the party, and beyond. Of course, such actions are likely to have the same effect as they did within the USSR - and many within the party are likely to take issue with an even harder Stalinist bend.
In Bulgaria the 'New Course' would mark a period of economic growth and industrialization - as well as the exploitation of more of the nation's mineral wealth and natural resources.

Chervenkov's open praise and idolization of Stalin has earned him increasing ire within the Bulgarian Communist Party. Attempts to further consolidate power into his own hands, undermine the institutions of the People's Republic, and purge opposition within the party all working to rob what little support he had within the nation. It was only support from Stalin himself that has, up until this point, provided any stability to his hold on power. However, with Stalin's passing Chervenkov has been left with few allies, and many within the party eager to see him removed from office. Already two voices have risen within the opposition - Zhivkov, who represents a more moderate faction within the party and Yugov who represents the remaining 'Home Communists' who seek a more Bulgarian path towards socialism and a distancing from the Soviet line. \n\n Of course, even without many allies, the strict Stalinist policies of Chervenkov have still left the leader with tools to use to cling to power against opposition - though its likely such actions would draw the ire of the USSR.

Chervenkov's open praise and idolization of Stalin has earned him increasing ire within the Bulgarian Communist Party. Even with his attempts to purge opposition and consolidate power largely blocked, his efforts to undermine the institution of the people's republic have never-the-less left him with few allies. Up until this point, however, his removal from power was out of the question due to his support from Stalin. With the Soviet leader's passing, the opportunity to make a move against Chervenkov has finally presented itself. \n\n Many of the most vocal opponents, such as Yugov and Kostov, are members of the 'Home Communist' faction that seek greater independence from the Soviet line and closer relations with Yugoslavia. Of course, more moderate members of the BCP have put forward their own candidate in Zhivkov.

Hoping to cling to power in the absence of his long-term ally, the late leader Stalin, Chervenkov has today instated a coup within the ranks of the BCP. Such a move has lead to wide-spread repression and instability throughout the nation - actions that threaten both the Bulgarian people and the rest of the Eastern Bloc. As such, many within the CPSU are requesting that the USSR intervene to depose this self-professed Stalinist and allow a more moderate leader to rise in his place.
With Soviet authority restored in Bulgaria and Chervenkov's powergrab at an end, the BCP - with Soviet approval - has reinstated its rule over the nation and put forward Zhivkov to lead the nation.

The April Line, or April Plenum, was envisioned as part of Bulgaria's process of De-Stalinization. Mostly revolving around the new line within the USSR in the wake of Stalin's death, the April line would set the party line moving forward and heavily emphasized the principles of shared leadership within the communist system as well as providing a strong rebuke of most of the ideas associated with Stalinism.

Even before the launch of Sputnik 1 by the USSR, Bulgaria had aspirations of its own for the creation of a space program. While the initial attempts to create such an agency, dependent on Soviet funding for their scope at the time, had been flatly rejected in the post-war climate the founding of such agencies in the USSR and its accomplishments would see renewed interest from Bulgarian intellectuals, the BCP, and even the army. \n\n Wanting to further build on this renewed interest, Air Force Captain Haralampiev and an engineer named Asparuhov would petition and meet with various members of Bulgarian society and government - eventually culminating on the establishment of the 'Bulgarian Astronautical Society', which itself would become the first such agency in the history of the nation.

Originally a member of the resistance against Axis-aligned Bulgaria and German forces stationed in the country, Elena Lagadinova earned herself a reputation as being one the youngest such partisans. However, it wasn't until after the war that her most famous feats would come to light. \n\n Taking advantage of the new regime and the freedom and stability that came with it she would shift her focus to the sciences. Legadinova would go on to earn a PhD in agribiology, joining the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences not long after where her expertise would go on to lead her to produce a more productive strain of wheat that greatly benefited the nation's agricultural output. Such a discovery would see her awarded the 'Order of Cyril and Methods' by the government and bring her even more into the public eye.

Hoping to fight against what he considered to be signs of a 'cult of personality', government 'excesses', and more abusive officials - Zhivkov put forward the idea of starting a campaign within the party and government of actively fighting against such things. Even going so far as to order any statue that had been build of himself to be removed, he hoped the moves - combined with the rehabilitation and reinstatement of figures purged under Chervenkov and a increase in cultural freedoms - would boost support for the government as well as control of more moderate voices within the BCP.

Hoping to make use of the mobile automatic phone that had been invented just a few years prior by Kupriyanovich in the USSR, Radioelektronika, a Bulgarian enterprise, presented its own designs and plans for the invention within Bulgaria. Starting with a single station in the capital, Radioelektronika hoped to spread its services throughout the nation - connection the nation with the new technology and further expanding upon it in the process.

The April Conspiracy refers to a planned coup against Bulgarian leader Zhivkov by radical Stalinist and Maoist elements within the BCP that perceived the revisionism of the General Secretary. The plot was led by Ivan Todorov-Gorunya and Tsolo Krastev in tandem with multiple elements of the Bulgarian military - though ultimately the plans would be discovered before they were executed and those that had involved themselves in it were swiftly arrested.

Bulgaria has been cast into a state of chaos after a recent coup against Zhivkov. According to reports, elements of the party, influenced by Maoism, have ousted what they claim were 'revisionist' leaders within the nation during a largely bloodless coup. The apparent leader of the coup, the hardline Todorov-Gorunya, has already started repressions against those speaking against the move - with a return to the days of Chervenkov looming over Bulgaria. Many within the party think it would be wise to intervene to put an end to this administration before it can cement its rule - restoring the elected leaders back to their posts and ensuring that more moderate voices prevail within the nation.

With Soviet authority restored in Bulgaria and the attempted Stalinist coup at an end, the BCP - with Soviet approval - has reinstated its rule over the nation and put forward Zhivkov to lead the nation once more.

Frustrated by what she perceived as interference within Bulgarian science by those without technical expertise and political influence within the sciences in general, Elena Lagadinova - already well known for her contributions to agricultural science - has petitioned the government with a complaint regarding the matter. \n\n Initially hoping to field her complaints, and recommendations, directly to the USSR - her letter would be intercepted and presented to Zhivkov. In response, Zhivkov moved to present Lagadinova with a ranking position within the party as president of the 'Fatherland Front' coalition that lead the nation, as well as to place her at the helm of the 'Bulgarian Women's Movement' - two positions that would enable her to not only ensure her recommendations were followed through but lead even more sweeping change in nation - and the larger world through participation in the Women's International Democratic Federation.

Inspired by the advent of Computer technology around the world, and having recently devised its own designs based on those in other nations - Bulgaria is poised to earn itself the title of 'Silicon Valley of the Eastern Bloc', becoming one of the foremost nations in the communist world for the production of computers and technological innovation in the field. While obviously this would require a massive initial investment by the government, many feel that the so-called 'cybernetisation' of the nation is the path forward for the socialist world.

In an effort to combat the growing liberal movement within the Bulgarian Communist party, as well as revisionist tendencies such as Eurocommunism, Zhivkov and the moderates within the party conducted a small-scale purge of vocal reformists within the party - expelling both they and their supporters through 1977 and 1978, as well as reorganizing the structures of the party itself.

Bulgaria's 'New Economic Mechanism' referred to a series of minor market reforms implemented throughout the nation. The exact policies were heavily inspired by those that had been undertaken earlier in the USSR itself, primarily focusing on a relaxing of price controls and more decentralization in the economy. The initial impact was a period of economic growth and an increase in popularity for the regime - as well as a stabilization of the still growing industrial economy.

The 'Revival Process', also known as the 'Process of Rebirth' was a forced assimilation campaign conducted in Bulgaria primarily targeting the Muslim and Turkish populations within the nation. Seen mainly as a nationalist undertaking, the campaign sought to 're-Christianize' elements of the country that - by more hardline nationalists within Bulgaria - had been themselves forcibly converted to Islam during the occupation by the Ottoman Empire. The actions that followed during the campaign would be met with wide-spread backlash from both the Muslim communities in Bulgaria as well as the reformist wing of the BCP - serving to only deepen the divide in the party.

With a new generation of those with technical expertise well on the way and already emerging into the workforce, and 'Cyberisation' proving a success, many within the party feel the time has come to begin the process of economic automation. While likely to be slow at first, hopes that it will prove to be the economic model of socialism moving forward and lead to an overall more prosperous Bulgaria outweigh potential fears over the new technology.

Change has swept across the USSR, and the Eastern Bloc at large. Now at the helm of politics, the prominent reformist politician Gorbachev has started the campaigns of 'Perestroika' and 'Glasnost' aiming to bring what the reformists have long claimed are needed reforms to its structures and institutions. \n\n While many, including Zhivkov himself, have their reservations about the reforms - they have none-the-less begun plans to carefully replicate them within the country. However, not everyone in the BCP is quite as cautious. Reformists, long stifled under the moderate regime, have pushed for a fully endorsement and imitation of the reforms - hoping to guide Bulgaria towards a more western-oriented style of communism.

Decree Number 56 was an order made by the Zhivkov administration primarily focused on market reforms in the nation. While the initial limited replication of reforms in the USSR had brought some minor change - the growing pressure to continue with reforms in the wake of the Soviet withdraw, as well as the backing of the BCP's more liberal minded elements, meant that further reforms were all but ensured.

With the situation in Bulgaria rapidly deteriorating, and the 'Revival Process' leading to increasing unrest in minority and Muslim communities - a drastic plan has been laid out by the regime. Called the 'Big Excursion', the plan calls for the opening of the border with Turkey in order to facilitate emigration of Turks from Bulgaria to the nation. \n\n However, reformists are furious over the plan - decrying it as genocide, while many more within the party worry that a mass exodus of people from Bulgaria and into Turkey would not only draw the ire of the Turkish regime but also rob Bulgaria of much-needed workforce. In either way, one thing is clear - the 'Revival Process' has drawn has led to an increasing animosity between the Muslim population and the ruling regime - with the most vocal dissent now emerging from the southern and eastern portions of the nation where they reside.

Despite Zhivkov's removal and commitments to elections and the introduction of more western style freedoms in the nation - unrest within Bulgaria has only grown. Protests and strikes spread across the nation as the reformists scramble to enact further reforms, making use of their newfound position of authority while it lasts.

Mladenov, along with other top leaders, have put forward the decision today to end the BCP's right to rule and govern over Bulgaria. Along side the announcement comes the end of the People's Republic, and a return to a 'Republic of Bulgaria' once again - with communist symbols and imagery already disappearing from flags, buildings, and documents. Additionally Mladenov and the more liberal-minded in the party hope to dissolve the BCP altogether, refounding it as the long disbanded 'Bulgarian Socialist Party' - with a now social democratic platform to replace the old Marxist-Leninist ideology.

With the end of the People's Republic of Bulgaria, a Constitutional Assembly has been called to decide the future of the nation. While numerous political parties have emerged to run in said elections, two dominant forces have risen above the rest as they lay out their vision for a western oriented Bulgarian state. The BSP, the reformed Communist Party, wishes to move away from the socialist past gradually while the Union of Democratic forces desires a rapid transition towards capitalism and a western style democracy. However, its likely that regardless of the winner, compromise and pressure from the public and the international community will play a substantial role in the shape of the new state.

Bulgaria's fourth constitution is set to soon be drafted and come into effect. Despite the composition of the national assembly, the draft proposed remained a compromise between the various forces that had won some number of seats in the election. The constitution is set to call for the creation of a parliamentary system with a basic separation of powers based on those in many western states. Additionally, this new constitution will enshrine multiple values wished for by opposition forces - namely regarding the recognition of the country's language and religion, its sovereignty, and several aspects of what is regarded as its culture.

While taking different forms in different places, having different motivations, and being both manipulated by and viewed in different lights by various political groups and portions of the population - its effect on the mindset and culture of the nations and peoples that experience it is hard to ignore. Across much of the former Soviet Union and Eastern Bloc the so-called 'Ostalgia' would go on to inspire voting patterns, art, culture, and even the rise of new organizations and ideologies. \n\n In Bulgaria, feelings of ostalgia would persist well into the modern day as the nation's economy deteriorated in the wake of the end of communism in the nation. Many of the people that had grown up earning a technical education or other specialized background now found themselves without a livelihood, and political instability - as well as integration into organizations like the EU and NATO - would only further cement these feelings as time passed among large portions of the population.
