Chervenkov, the unquestioned leader of Bulgaria for decades now, has today passed away. In his wake, the efforts that he put into place to build support for his - still small - Stalinist faction have begun to bear fruit. While the nation mourns and preparations for a funeral commence, talks within the party have begun on who should replace Chervenkov as leader of Bulgaria, and if the ideology of Stalinism should continue to lead the country into the future. \n\n The two most prominent choices currently are that of Todorov-Gorunya - a self-professed Stalinist heavily inspired by Chinese Maoism - and Dragoycheva whose support for the Soviet line and more hardline policies has earned her the parties' approval as a potential force to carry on the late leader's legacy.

With the 'Home Communist' faction now finally achieving for itself some manner of power in the nation there have been talks to reassess the BCP's party line and overall platform. Up until now, Bulgaria's policies have closely mirrored that of those in the Soviet Union and other WTO nations with only minor deviation as the need arose or politics within the government shifted in favor of change - however, the 'Home Communists' wish a more independent and distinctly 'Bulgarian' approach towards building communism in the nation. Many of them hope to push for a replication of the 'Market Socialism' followed in Yugoslavia under Tito, as well as greater cooperation and trade to help further stimulate the economy.

Anton Yugov has announced today his intentions to step away from political life - effectively retiring from his posts, a move driven on by the internal conflicts within the party and his own declining health. In his wake moves have already been made to seek a successor - with the most prominent voices coming from the more hardline factions, seeking a restoration of ties with the USSR and more orthodox views of communism being enacted in the nation. However, the reformists have also made moves to propel themselves into power, with Mladenov praising many of Yugov's policies - calling for a continuation of reforms within Bulgaria and for the nation to forge its own path towards communism.

Seeking even more radical change in the country and its structures than merely reforms to its economic system, Kostov today has put forward the draft to a sweeping constitutional change that would see Bulgaria reshaped in what Kostov himself calls a more 'Bulgarian' image. The new constitution is set to provide a departure from the previous Soviet inspired constitution, primarily focusing on removing the more overt imitation of Soviet structures and the reestablishing of several previously abolished administrative divisions - as well as the creation of entirely new systems to replace the old. The draft also includes mentions of Bulgaria's position in the Balkans, emphasizing cooperation and friendship with Yugoslavia - something that had been discouraged by the USSR in the wake of the split between Tito and Stalin.

Bulgaria has long been in the Soviet shadow, with its internal politics and policies at times being influenced by the de facto leader of the WTO. While many within the party are content with that state of affairs, seeing the Soviet Union's presence in Bulgaria as a stabilizing force, many of the more radical and nationalist leaning 'Home Communists' see it as something worth rectifying. Kostov and his allies have made the proposal to officially begin the move towards independence. \n\n While such a move isn't unique or out of the question for the - technically equal - members of the WTO, the USSR even still might perceive Bulgaria's moves as a threat to the communist bloc, or its own influence within Eastern Europe. However, given Bulgaria intends to remain part of the WTO it is unlikely to result in an invasion on its own, though the consequences of withdraw could embolden the opposition and prompt concerns in Moscow in Kostov's ability to lead the nation.

Bulgaria has formally petitioned us to remove troops from within their country and lesson influence over their domestic politics - moves that would remove much of the control the Soviet Union is currently able to exert on the nation. The Warsaw Treaty's principles mean such a move is well within Bulgaria's right, however even still some within the party's more hardline factions have expressed concerns over the possibility of leaving the nation. \n\n Instead these groups have raised fears that unrest could grow in the nation in the absence of Soviet troops, or of more liberal-minded elements within the party taking advantage of a lack of direct Soviet support for their own aims - claims that have been rebuffed by moderates and reformists who instead focus on stability within the Warsaw Pact as a whole over maintaining a tight grip on Europe.

Bulgaria's attempt at independence has been put to an end today as Soviet troops instated Zhivkov and pro-Soviet moderates in the place of the now ousted 'Home Communists', with the new government already taking steps to secure its own stability.

With Kostov's death, the end has come to a long period of 'Home Communist' dominance in Bulgarian politics. While its likely that the faction will remain in a position of authority within the BCP for decades to come, the decision remains inconclusive within the party as to which faction will come out on top of Bulgarian politics. Many would be content with moderates that will continue on the party line with little change, while others support either the reformists or hardliners - each with their own view of Bulgarian socialism.

Dragoycheva has always been a vocal supporter of Bulgarian integration into the USSR as a member republic, however until now her dream of leading the nation towards becoming the next Soviet Socialist Republic has been outweighed by a desire within the party to keep the nation firmly independent. With her and her allies at the helm this idea has now been propelled into the mainstream - with serious conversations now taking place within the party amid mounting tensions. Ultimately, however, any decision is contingent fully on the Soviet response - which has so far been one of caution about expanding its borders via Bulgarian integration.

Bulgaria's leadership has formally petitioned to begin the process of becoming a Soviet Socialist Republic - a move that has been met with caution and surprise within the party. While many within the party would wholly accept the proposal - something that draws the USSR closer to the ideals of both Pan-Slavism and Eurasianism - many more have expressed concern that such a move could be viewed more negatively in the international community and remain skeptical of the support behind the idea within Bulgaria itself. However, ultimately the choice is ours as to whether to accept the proposal - with either possibility resulting in closer ties to our ally.

The Soviet leadership have declined the prospect of integration, for now - having emphasized the unity between the Bulgarian and Soviet people in their rejection. Hopefully, they claim, one day the two peoples will be ready to become one. Until then, Bulgaria remains as an independent nation.

Gorbachev's rise within the Soviet Union was met with uncertainty by the Dragoycheva administration despite its zealously pro-soviet attitude, a feeling only exacerbated by not only the materialization of these reforms within the USSR but by an increasing pressure on the member states of the WTO to enact reforms of their own mirroring that of the agenda of the Soviet reformists. \n\n Even with hardliners at the helm, Bulgaria has been unable to escape the bulk of that pressure. Dragoycheva has found herself personally approached by Soviet officials - with support from the BCP's own reformists - to make market reforms in the nation, many of which would be unlikely to draw the backing of more hardline elements within the party. Even still, failing to pass even a limited version of these reforms could prove problematic - with the Soviets possibly turning their support away from the government and towards the reformist wing of the party.

The ripples having been set out by Gorbachev's reforms in the USSR have finally reached Bulgaria. Demonstrations, strikes, and protests have been set ablaze across the nation calling for reforms and change. While most claim to only wish for changes within the framework of socialism, many other groups have arisen to join the movements that demand even more radical change - with their numbers growing with each passing day. Many within the party have proposed swift action while the movements remain relatively isolated, hoping to prevent violence against the regime as well as to ensure to continuation of a more orthodox line in the nation.

With Dragoycheva's passing, the nation is left to mourn its long-time leader while the varied factions of the party move to push for their own candidates to fill the now vacant office. While the most likely candidate is the more hardline Todorov-Gorunya, Lilov - a moderate - and Mladenov - a reformer - have been vocal in courting members of the party and public. In any case, its likely that whoever comes to lead Bulgaria will set the agenda and line of the party moving forward - bringing the nation into the future.

Inspired by Maoist thought, Todorov-Gorunya has made moves to start a sweeping campaign across the nation modeled off of the theory and experiences of the Chinese leader. Dubbing it as a 'Cultural Revolution' after the campaign that inspired it, he hopes to achieve the same effect in Bulgaria of moving the country closer to a revolutionary mindset - as well as purging remaining elements of reaction. While some more moderate voices in the party have expressed concern over the move, the unease has been somewhat sated by the smaller scale of the project and changes based on China's own experiences.

Todorov-Gorunya has announced his retirement from Bulgarian politics today, his advancing age seeing him increasingly drawing from public life. While its unlikely the stalwart Stalinists grip on power will decline until his passing - the party has already begun to discuss who should serve as a replacing. \n\n The main divide the party, now heavily populated by the outgoing leader's allies, is between those supporting a more moderate candidate and those supporting the continuation of hardline Stalinism in the nation.

The decision to appoint the scientist Elena Lagadinova to the high position she now enjoys, while controversial at the time among many within the party, has drawn the interest of an emerging faction within the ranks of the BCP. Lagadinova's presence in the government, they claim, has been an overall positive force - positive enough to replicate. Their efforts have already seen many fellow technical experts elevated to high positions in the party, however they are seemingly not content with their influence in the government. Instead, they hope to take advantage of the technocratic bend that Bulgarian society, and government, has taken to replace the currently General Secretary Zhivkov with their own Lagadinova - hoping to usher in a period of technocracy within the government.

Uranium has been located within the Plovdiv province, a discovery that will enable Bulgaria to explore a host of options in regards to nuclear power and beyond. However, an initial investment from the government is needed in order to fund the initial work in getting to and extracting these resources safely.

Lagadinova, citing declining age and a desire to step back from politics, has announced her intent to retire from her leadership position within Bulgaria. Instead, she has left the party to decide who will fill in the now vacant position. While years of technocratic dominance have ensured that there is a good chance that such policies continue on, reformists and hardliners have begun their own campaign to lobby support within the party - hoping to revive their power and push for less pragmatic technocracy.

The process of automation in Bulgaria carries on, with the small-scale experiments having proven to be massive successes. Preparations have already been made to begin carrying out similar changes and reforms all across the country - with a new generation of experts, programmers, and more ready to staff the newly created jobs while structural changes within the apparatuses of the Bulgarian government commence in earnest.

With the advent of new technology, the possibility has arisen to take Bulgarian automation to an even higher stage. While the current system on its own is efficient, many have proposed creating a national network - allowing for even more instant communication between various factories and farms not only with planners but one another and the various automated systems that have enabled us to more accurately and efficiently steer the economy. All that would be needed is an initial investment into creating the infrastructure, as well updating existing systems.

Mladenov and his fellow reformists have made no secret of their admiration for their ideological allies within the CPSU, especially the more vocal figures within the faction. The rise of these forces within the USSR has only emboldened this idolization further - with a heavy focus on the programs and policies now being enacted by Soviet leader Gorbachev. The sweeping and drastic changes, referred to as 'Glasnost' and 'Perestroika', have earned praise from Mladenov, who hopes to enact similar such changes within Bulgaria itself. While its likely such a move is, similar to in the USSR, upset more moderate or hardline elements within the party - its also likely to bring further backing from the Soviets, who will surely support their fellow reformists within the WTO.

Changes are sweeping across the Warsaw Pact in the wake of the changes taking place in the Soviet Union, as well as a dwindling line of support to its allied states. While Bulgaria's situation itself is mostly stable, there are still growing calls to move towards a more western model for the nation - a move that Reformists have been receiving warmly so far. Mladenov himself has already drafted a new Bulgarian constitution - calling on the restoration of elements of western democracy in the nation and a move away from the communist system that has dominated the country for decades.

With the radical changes that have come to Bulgaria in the past few years, calls for further reforms to the structure and position of the party itself have begun to emerge from more liberal elements in society. Many are calling on the BCP to fully abandon Marxism-Leninism as a party line, something that is now seen as no longer applicable to the conditions within Bulgaria - instead urging the party to refound itself as a social democratic party, and importantly to give up its dominant position in politics.

With his health in decline, Mladenov has announced his retirement from politics today - leaving his post vacant for the time being. As the party and National Assembly each take steps to fill and reshuffle positions in his new-found absence a question has been posed to the party on its future. While the most obvious choice would be to continue the reformist line set by Mladenov and his allies, there still remains within the BCP a hardline tendency - with many eager to see many of the more unpopular market reforms reversed entirely. Either choice is likely to determine Bulgaria's course for several years to come.

With hardliners in the party - Stalinists, Maoists, and Orthodox Marxist-Leninists - allowed to continue to grow and gain influence within not only the party, but the government and society as well, it was only a matter of time before they made moves to further their agenda. Two prominent members have already risen up as potential replacements for Zhivkov - who now faces an ouster from his former posts. Dragoycheva, a hardliner whose pro-Soviet stance makes her an excellent pick for closer relations with the USSR and continued stability in the nation, and Todorov-Gorunya, whose blend of Stalinism and Maoist thought could bring more radical change to the nation.

With the party's reformist wing steadily gaining influence and support within both the government, party, and greater Bulgarian society - it was only a matter of time before it made moves to undermine the authority of its rival factions. Mladenov, the leader of the reformists, has formally announced his intentions to challenge Zhivkov's position - now having enough backing to follow through. Even still, its likely hardliners and moderates alike will unite together in the wake of what they are already calling a 'party coup' - eagerly waiting for a chance to steer the nation away from whatever direction the reformists might guide it towards.

With Zhivkov's advancing age, the Bulgarian leader today has announced he is stepping down from his position of power within the government and party. In his wake the BCP has already begun the process of electing his successor, with the choice tied between Lilov and Paunov - both moderate candidates who show promise in ensuring continued stability within the socialist state.

The rumblings of unrest have started to rise to the surface within Romania, with various factions of the party beginning to take issue more vocally with the mismanagement of the Ceausescu regime. Recently several vocal dissidents within the party issued a letter - called the 'Letter of the Six' - calling on a resignation of the Romanian leader. Chief among these voices is, Apostol, a self-described 'Reformist-Stalinist' who seeks to guide the nation back towards a more orthodox path. \n\n Given that our position is relatively stable, we are presented with the opportunity to potentially help nudge the course of events in our allied state. A few within the party have put forward an idea to help oust Ceausescu, putting Apostol and other dissidents in his place within the party - a move that, while drastic, would surely set the nation on a more ideologically sound course. However, others within the party have pointed out that Romania's reformists could also prove to be a viable choice - hoping to court support for their own allies abroad in any potential intervention.

The Soviet withdraw from Afghanistan means a potential defeat for the Communist regime in the country - having already been forced to make numerous concessions in attempts to reach an end to the bloody conflict against the Mujahideen. However, some within the party have proposed that - given our own country's situation - we could spare resources to aid the regime in hopes that it might prove enough to ensure victory for the regime. Such a move, however, would likely draw the ire of the international community.

Zhivkov's actions in starting a mass campaign of assimilation within the nation has slowly drawn an increasing disdain for his rule - not only from the Muslim and Turkish communities within Bulgaria - but from reformists who have already been vocal in their dissatisfaction with the Bulgarian leader's efforts to embrace their proposed agenda. Without intervention, its likely that the situation will boil over into an eventual confrontation between this increasingly powerful faction and Zhivkov's own administration. However, we are currently in a position to tip the scales - decisive support for Zhivkov could be enough to ensure the leader remains in his office, though our own reformists think it would be wise to help push for Zhivkov's resignation instead.

Built in 1974 and inaugurated on 23 August 1981, the Monument House of the Bulgarian Communist Party, commonly known as Buzludzha Monument, celebrates her 50th Birthday. The triumphing futuristic looking buildings has since her foundation been a Hallmark of Socialist Development and during the last decades held different cultural events for the whole citizenry. The Chairman during the celebrations held a speech describing the importance of this symbol in the history of the nation.

150 Years ago on the Bozludzha Peak Dmitri Blagoev and other fellow-minded individuals founded the Bulgarian Social Democratic Party, the forerunner of our Bulgarian Communist Party. This date signs a day of great importance for all citizens of our country. The Party celebrates 150 Years of Struggle and advancement of the proletarian cause, as tell the remarks of the Chairman on this lucky day. The whole of Bulgaria is in feast and various marches and gatherings have been organized to celebrate the festivity.

Originally met with ridicule due to its perceived absurdity by fellow engineers, the proposal of Soviet aerospace engineer Mikhail Tikhonravov to use multi-staged rockets to increase flight range has finally gained widespread recognition. Leading a team of researchers, he has been able to not only conduct important tests to verify his idea, but already begun laying out the designs for various probes to be used for space exploration.

Leonid Kupriyanovich, a prominent Soviet engineer already well-known for his work on creating more portable versions of various communication devices throughout the 50s, has recently come to the government with a rather unique innovation that is sure to bring radical chance to the field - being among the first of its kind in the world. He claims to have created a mobile version of the phone, showing off prototypes for a device that is small enough to fit in the palm of the hand. Already plans have been made for the mass production of this device and its further improvement and specialization, not only for various fields such as the medical and military professions, but for the general public as well - including the creation of a network for these devices around Moscow and other larger cities.
The Bozludzha Monument

The Bozludzha Monument, officially known as the Monument House of the Bulgarian Communist Party, is, as the name tells, a monument house to the History of Bulgaria and her Communist Party. The building is going to be built on the historical site of the foundation of the Communist Party in 1891, and nonetheless in the proximity was fought the last battle between Ottoman forces and the Bulgarian Revolutionaries in 1868 and in 1944 a German Army detachment was defeated there by partisans. The building is gonna be 70 meters tall and host inside its perimeters a museum to Bulgarian history and various mosaics to celebrate Communism and its achievements.
Xue Muqiao

A Chinese economist, Xue Muqiao would focus his studies and works on the development of socialism and theories of productive forces. In particular, he would coin the term 'underdeveloped socialism' in his analysis of the mainland Chinese economy and set the framework for the later policies and positions of conservative reformists in the CPC.
Structural Realism

Structural Realism, also known as Neorealism, in international relations refers to a mentality and policy outlook that views the international system as inherently uncooperative and power-based. It posits the need for displays of strength and power by nations in order to exert sovereignty over themselves and influence over other states.
Dependency Theory

Dependency Theory is an international relations perspective heavily influenced by Marxism. It posits that the world is divided into 'core' and 'periphery' states, with the former exploiting the latter to enrich itself and creating structures that perpetuate this exploitation. It arose primarily as a way to critique neoimperialism as well as to explain the lack of development in Latin American and Africa.
E-Government

Primarily seen as a way to improve participation within government, the concept of E-government is one rooted in growing technological advances and innovations, primarily the advent of the internet. Such systems allow for bodies of authority to provide services, functions, and more through non-traditional mediums and reach a much wider selection of people than would otherwise be possible for much less effort.
Cyberocracy

Cyberocracy refers to a speculative form of government in which society and governance is structured based on the efficient use of information facilitated by technological advances that allow a rapid - hypothetically near instantaneous - dissemination and processing of information.
Continentalism

Continentalism refers to a foreign policy outlook that favors regional cooperation, usually along continental lines - taking various forms such as integration, unification, or merely alliances and economic unions.
Indigenismo

Emerging primarily in the Latin American countries, 'Indigenismo' refers to an ideology that emphasizes the relationship between Indigenous communities and centers of authority. Primarily it focuses on expanding political, civil, and cultural rights or even outright independence or autonomy.
Vertical Farming

Vertical Farming refers to a wide range of practices with the goal of reducing the space taken up by agriculture while increasing the yield. Traditionally this is accomplished by stacking crops, using hydroponics, automation, aeroponics, and many more practices. This method, its proponents claim, also allows for a more ecofriendly or even carbon-negative impact on the environment.
Stem Cell Treatment

Stem Cell Treatment refers to the use of 'Stem cells' - unspecialized cells able to reform themselves to fit any role in the body - in treating various diseases and conditions. The versatility they hold enables regenerative treatments of nerve cells and other organs and areas of the body that otherwise would be unable to heal or regrow on their own.
Full Body Replacement

The transhumanist dream has become a reality as the human body has become almost completely obsolete, with a replacement for nearly every organ and limb available - as well as completely new bodies able to be custom-designed and utilized on a whim.
CT Scanner

Also known as a 'CAT scan' - the computed tomography scan allows for noninvasive imaging of the body for the purposes of diagnoses and treatment. Utilizing x-ray technology, it operates by rotating a tube and a row of detectors around the patient.
MRI
The MRI, or Magnetic Resonance Imaging, utilizes magnetic fields to map out the processes and functionality of the body - enabling better diagnoses and treatment.
Basic Bionic Prosthetics

Bionic Prosthetics refers to prosthetic limbs that are controlled or augmented with electronics - usually allowing them to be controlled by those utilizing them via either the brain or an external device. The advent of bionic prosthetics greatly improved the use of prosthetic limbs, enabling a wider range of motion and functionality.
Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

The Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator, as the name implies, is a version of the defibrillator device able to be placed inside and function within the body - enabling it to automatically correct irregular heartbeats or other abnormal cardiac functioning.
Advanced Bionic Prosthetics

Rather than simply replacing lost limbs, prosthetic technology has emerged that can entirely surpass the functionality of normal human limbs. As this technology disseminates through the population, its likely to revolutionize society - as well as improve productivity and quality of life.
Modular Prosthetics

Technology in the field of prosthetics has advanced to the point where few limitations remain on what is possible. Artificial tails, legs with super-speed, and arms able to vastly outcompete their human counterparts. With the advent of this technology the human body has been made almost completely modular.

At the 2nd National Congress of the PDPA Chairman Sarwari exposed him plan to bring back harmony to the country, plan that he dubbed the National Renewal Campaign. The Campaign will also try to expand party membership and the creation of a Commission for Ethnic Issues.

The Central Committee has long been discussing the resignation of Afghanistan's PDPA Babrak Karmal due to the budget drain he has been inflicting on our national coffers. In the last few years the Leader of the DRA hasn't managed to make any significant progress in his fight for national consolidation nor to end the war, while the USSR's public opinion was smeared internationally and the army overextended. Now that Karmal is conducting a State Visit in Moscow it seems like it could be the right time to confront him about resignation and allow for a better suited Chairman to take over the Party and hopefully end the war on his favour.

With the dissolution of the USSR the Socialist Camp faces its most tumultuous time yet as shocking news sends powerful ripples across Eastern Europe - the cracks already starting to form as governments brace for the worst. Its likely that such a massive change to the political landscape of not only Europe, but the world at large, will spell disaster for many regimes. Even within our own nation forces have started to muster, hoping to take advantage of the chaos that might ensue and use the unfolding situation to fulfill their own goals.

With the chaotic situation in the country both economically and politically, murmurs within the parties more fringe factions have started to buzz ever louder. Chief among these are the so-called 'Reformists', supporters of market reforms, democratization, liberalization, and even closer ties with the West. While in better times such forces could easily be dismissed - the current situation is far from ideal. \n\n Already several prominent members of these groups have approached the leadership with an ultimatum, that being to cede power to them or face a number of threats ranging from vague unrest to outright civil war. While many hardliners are sure to resent what is an apparent coup against the regime from within, it might be best to give into the more moderate demands rather than risk even further destabilization.

With Reformists now firmly within a position of power and the situation still declining, a proposal for a sweeping liberalization both politically and economically has been put forward. This includes extended recognition of private ownership, the reorganization of opposition parties, lessoning the power and authority of the communist party, and opening the country's foreign policy towards its former enemies in the west. While its likely that these changes could help stop the rapid changes sweeping across the nation, it would serve as another step away from socialism and towards a more western-style of governance and economics.

Amid the perceived collapse of Marxism-Leninism an unthinkable proposition has been put forward as part of the continued changes sweeping the nation - and the larger Socialist Camp at large. The more radical reformists have put forward the idea of completely abandoning the party's platform entirely, washing away Marxism-Leninism and instead embracing what they claim is a more pragmatic ideology of social democracy. Such a move would almost certainly spell the end of the current, shaky, status quo - though few remain to oppose the reformists as they continue the charge away from the East.

The reforms made by the more liberal-minded within the communist party have reached the conclusion many feared from the start. Opposition parties, organized under a broad banner of neoliberalism and integration into the global economic system set up by the west, are using the newfound changes to the country's laws and constitution to continue where the reformists have left off. Already protests have erupted across the nation, packed with supporters for these new organizations as they demand for the complete democratization of the nation and free elections - as well as guaranteed representation in any new government that might form in the future.

With Reformists already making up a sizable force within our nation, we have averted the fate of many of the more hardline regimes as they deal with attempted party coups and unrest among the varied factions within them. Instead, those same forces within our nation have put forward similar demands in a much more constructive manner - citing the declining situation and the dwindling number of paths forward as evidence of the necessity of the bold changes they suggest. Even still, the more stable situation affords us a greater opportunity to attempt to weather the storm currently facing the Socialist Camp, with more hardline elements already making preparations to do whatever it takes to stay the course.

This temporary, sporadic peace, solidified in the Treaty of Varkiza, has fallen short of the promises made in it. While the treaty promised the communist forces amnesty, retained the legality of the KKE, and offered a referendum on the status of Greece's monarchy - a reign of 'White Terror' followed not long after that resulted in the deaths of hundreds of former partisans and the arrest of many thousand more, effectively nullifying many of the treaty's promises. With the Cold War now on the horizon and communist governments consolidating themselves across Eastern Europe, many within Greece see the prospects of peace dwindling even further.

However, as the situation in the world changes so does the Greece's own. Civil War is once again a threat to the nation, with only time serving to tell if the tenuous peace will continue to hold.

Elections are scheduled to be held in the wider Greece in March, with the fate of the elections likely to play a strong factor in the promised referendum on the monarchy scheduled for later in the year. This would be an opportunity to, alongside our former allies in the EAM, to stand for election as part of a broad left coalition and potentially make good on our previous goal of working towards the establishment of a 'People's Democracy' in the nation. However, such a prospect is not one that the leadership of the KKE has expressed little interest or optimism within. \n\n In the wake of the campaigns of white terror, mostly unchecked by the Greek State, the most hardline members of the party are adamant that any election - or referendum - conducted by the Greek state would be fraudulent, in favor of the monarchist parties. Instead, calls to push for the complete liberation of Greece continue to grow louder within the ranks of the KKE - with many more emboldened as the confrontation between the USSR and USA slowly begins to flare.

The KKE has announced its sudden intentions to boycott the upcoming elections scheduled for March. While such a move was not entirely unexpected given the tumultuous situation in the north of the country - it does serve to further drive a rift in the peace process, effectively killing any hope for a peaceful resolution between the conflict between the former partisan forces and the Greek government. Many within the military are already preparing for any potential action, with efforts to continue the disarmament of the ex-partisans redoubled as the cloud of civil war looms once more.

The KKE has, in a surprising move given the previous direction of its rhetoric, restated its commitment to participating in the upcoming Greek elections. While this bodes well for the fate of the Treaty between the Greek government and the former partisan forces - many express concerns of their own. Win, or loss, the KKE would feel itself emboldened by support within our own government and among the population.

With the situation in Greece as tense as it has been in over a year, the kindling has been laid out to be set aflame into yet another Civil War. Former partisans, angered by the actions of the Greek government and bitter over their efforts to bring liberation to the country boring a foreign backed regime aligned with the forces of reaction, have already started to collect arms and ammunition from stockpiles hidden after the treaty was signed - with many more already preparing actions of their own. \n\n Given the circumstances within the nation, and the world, the treaty seems set to fall apart without intervention from the KKE's leadership - who up to now have reiterated the desire to push for a military solution to the issue of Greece's fate.

Today, ahead of the elections scheduled for the March 31, a group of communist partisans - operating under the authority of the KKE's central leadership - attacked a police station in Litochoro. While the attack itself killed 14 people who were at the station at the time, it also has served to set in motion what many in the government had feared up until this point - a resumption of hostilities with the communist forces. Already groups across the north are rearming, with their strongholds casting off government control as Greece enters the third - and hopefully final - phase of its civil war.

The conflict between Tito and Stalin has finally reached a breaking point - with the two nations publicly announcing a break in relations with one another. For Greece, like the rest of the Balkans, this means a choice between adhering to the Soviet line or aligning fully with Yugoslavia. While, on the surface, such a choice seems simple given Tito's vocal and active support for the Greek communist partisans - many within the KKE's leadership hold sympathies to the Soviet model of communism, or in the case of the general secretary, Zachariadis, an adherence to Stalinist doctrine. \n\n Even still, there are many within the KKE and the wider communist movement that support Yugoslavia, and even outright declare themselves to be 'Titoists' - including the head of the provisional government, Vafeiadis. As the party's representatives gather to hold a vote on the official line of the KKE, its likely both factions and their respective heads will end up coming to conflict - an event likely to change the course of Greece should it attain its liberation, as well as effect the manner in which the civil war must be conducted.

With the KKE's decision to side with the Soviets in the Tito-Stalin split, the party has been thrown into a state of chaos. Hundreds of members have been expelled on accusations of Titoism, with many more quitting outright - with splits forming in the larger partisan movement based around the decision. While in the long term this could mean a more united party, in the short term it will likely greatly impede the ability to wage war against the capitalists, as well as hold the already disparate provisional government together.

Not all partisans remained in Greece following the end of hostilities outlined in the Treaty of Varkiza. Many, seeking to avoid any potential actions by the reactionary government, had fled to nations across Eastern Europe - with weapons and family in tow. Now, with civil war erupting in Greece once more, many of these brave fighters have returned to offer their assistance - hoping to finally reclaim their home from the British puppets.

The General Command has issued an order proclaiming that all partisan groups be unified under a single banner - that being of the newly created Democratic Army of Greece. Vafeiadis, a leading figure of the among the communist forces and already in a leadership position among the partisan groups, is set to assume leadership over the forces. Its hoped that by reorganizing the disparate partisan groups around the country, a more effective fighting force can be created to fight in the struggle for liberation and people's democracy.

The KKE, together with the newly proclaimed Democratic Army of Greece, have today announced the creation of the Provisional Government of Greece - a more coherent and structured governing body for the budding socialist state emerging across the north of the country. The move, part of a larger strategy of increasing the legitimacy of the communist forces both domestically and internationally, has already started to bare fruit as the new government presents itself as the liberators of Greece, evoking the resistance during the Second World War - of which many members of new government were involved prior to joining the communist cause after the conclusion of the war and first stages of conflict.

Across the north of Greece there are many Slavic peoples - notably Bulgarians and Macedonians - have taken up arms together with Greeks against their capitalist oppressors. These groups, long pushed to the fringe by the Kingdom of Greece and its predecessors, now have a shot at liberation. As such, the Provisional Government has announced a decision that, after the conclusion of the Civil War, both groups are to be given equal status within the new nation.

Military aid and equipment have arrived today from Bulgaria - with the communist government there voicing its support for our cause. Already we've begun putting the equipment, mostly leftover from the Second World War, to use in supplying our partisans. This will surely go a long way not only to embolden our movement, but further cement our relations with the emerging socialist bloc.

In a bold show of support, Bulgarian soldiers today have moved across the border into southern Macedonia and Thrace - securing positions in the name of the provisional communist government and driving out paramilitary groups supported by the West and their allies in Athens. While such a daring move is likely to put the west on edge and further isolate Bulgaria, it has only deepened support between our two nations as both peoples work towards revolution.

Military aid and equipment have arrived today from Albania - with the communist government there voicing its support for our cause. Already we've begun putting the equipment, mostly leftover from the Second World War, to use in supplying our partisans. This will surely go a long way not only to embolden our movement, but further cement our relations with the emerging socialist bloc.

In a bold show of support, Albanian soldiers today have moved across the border into Epirus - securing positions in the name of the provisional communist government and driving out paramilitary groups supported by the West and their allies in Athens. While such a daring move is likely to put the west on edge and further isolate the new Albanian state, it has only deepened support between our two nations as both peoples work towards revolution.

Long having provided us arms and aid, Yugoslavia has yet again reaffirmed its support for our cause. Long vocal support has grown even more as equipment, mainly leftover from the Second World War, has flowed with increasing frequency across the border. Already the equipment is being put to use in arming partisans, solidifying the friendship between the Yugoslav and Greek peoples.

In a bold and daring show of their commitment to revolution in Greece, Yugoslavia has announced it will be deploying troops in Southern Macedonia to help secure the region for the provisional communist government - helping to maintain order as well as drive out western-backed paramilitary groups operating in the region. While such a move is likely to heavily isolate Yugoslavia from the West, it has only deepened support between our two nations, both peoples working towards the common goal of liberation and revolution across the Balkans.

Distancing from his former policy on the question of revolution in Greece, Stalin today has announced today that the Soviet government will be providing arms and aid to the Greek partisans. Already the Soviet equipment - more advanced than the outdated leftovers from the Second World War - has been put to use in equipping our forces. Additionally advisors and economic aid from the Soviets has also reached us, further emboldening the partisans - as well as strengthening the position of the pro-Moscow elements of the KKE.

The Democratic Army of Greece, operating together with partisan groups working within the areas controlled by the western supported Greek government, have made a stunning push into Attica. This move has effectively put the lands under our nominal control - though effective government has yet to be established and already the forces of reaction have begun to launch their own counterattack. Many within the provisional government think it would be wise to direct our efforts to hold these territories until we can establish more effective governance - hoping to use a victory over Attica to mount a final push towards Athens proper.

Partisan groups aligned with the communist rebels have worked together with communist forces to mount a push into Attica - effectively wrestling control of the region from the legitimate authorities there. While this marks a massive setback for the Hellenic Army, many remain confident that we can turn the tide - though they emphasize that we should act quickly lest the communists be bolstered by their victory in the region.

Effective control over the territories of Attica has been secured - and with it the manpower and resources put at our disposal. The establishment of effective control over these areas is likely to be a massive boon to our own forces while serving to further drive the capitalists from Greece.

Another loss for the legitimate government of Greece has come today as the communists have managed to secure the lands in Attica they had previously occupied - effectively making these provinces part of their 'provisional government'. While this marks a massive setback to Greece, the Hellenic Army continues its struggle for unity and peace.

Partisan forces within Corinthia have risen up in the midst of the Civil War, managing to secure parts of the region for the Provisional government - and working to drive out the reactionaries from their homes. Already the people welcome their liberation from the oppressive British backed government, with fighters filling our ranks as the provisional government moves to integrate them into the larger Democratic Army of Greece.

Across Corinthia rebels are rising to the call made by the communist provisional government, with most of the fighting taking place in the northern reaches of the region. While they have successfully managed to oust local authorities from most of the smaller towns - the Hellenic Army and police forces have already begun making preparations for a counter-offensive, hoping to rob the communists of their short-lived victory and reassert their authority.

The Situation on Crete had long differed from that on the mainland. While the ELAS had been dissolved and disarmed in larger Greece - due to the unique situation that had unfolded on the island the ELAS remained armed and active. However, even still - it had mostly honored the tenuous peace established by the Treaty of Varkiza, an uneasy truce established with local authorities on the island. This truce lasted even after the resumption of hostilities on the mainland, with the still armed and active branch of ELAS largely isolated of the larger struggles taking place across Greece. \n\n That has isolation, as well as the peace, have seemingly been broken however. Operating on orders from the mainland, the Cretan authorities have made a series of arrests across the island - provoking an armed response from the island's communist forces as they join the fight for liberation once more, pledging their support to the provisional government and launching a full scale insurgency to take control of Crete.

However, even still - it had mostly honored the tenuous peace established by the Treaty of Varkiza, an uneasy truce established with local authorities on the island. This truce lasted even after the resumption of hostilities on the mainland, with the still armed and active branch of ELAS largely isolated of the larger struggles taking place across Greece. \n\n That isolation has seemingly been broken. Acting on orders from Athens, local authorities have moved to attempt to preempt any insurgency on the island - succeeding only in provoking the still armed partisans on the island into a full scale insurgency. Already the local remnants of the ELAS have pledged themselves to the newly formed Democratic Army of Greece, taking up positions on the island and threatening to rob Greece of control over yet more of its territory.

Resigning to its fate, the British backed government of traitors in Athens has chosen to flee the country entirely. Thousands of supporters of the regime, as well as its major officials and ruling organs, have already made a hasty retreat in the wake of the advances of our partisan forces - leaving the people of Greece to chaos and uncertainty as they await liberation and a swift restoration of order under the provisional government. Instead the former officials and authorities have made their way to Cyprus, reviving a Second World War era plan to setup a 'government in exile' on the island. \n\n Already, the government there has started to take shape and organize - taking the reigns from the local colonial authorities, presenting itself as 'liberators' of the Cypriot Greeks, and reasserting its 'legitimacy' as the sole government of Greece. While challenging their claim in Cyprus is currently an impossibility given the status of the nation - there is no doubt among the people of Greece that the Provisional government is the legitimate governing body, with much of the socialist world taking our side as one by one they recognize our government over that of the now 'exiled' one in Cyprus.

With the last remnants of the Greek government on the retreat, the time has finally come to proclaim our victory in the Civil War. While Greece has been ravaged by this conflict, from the ashes liberation and prosperity will come. Already the framework of a new Greek state has begun to emerge, with spontaneous organizations popping up across the country as partisan groups return to their normal life - celebrating a victory for socialism that will ring across Europe.

While the Provisional Government, headed by the leadership of the KKE, acted as the de facto authority in the Communist held areas of Greece during a majority of the Civil War - this informal and inefficient structure has finally outlived its usefulness. Instead, the time has come to write a new constitution for Greece that will serve as a foundation for a true People's Democracy. Given the Marxist-Leninist leanings of the KKE, and their prominence within the partisan movement, it only seems natural that a majority of those that now find themselves in a position of power seek to emulate the emerging states across Eastern Europe - notably Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union. However, some instead have proposed an alternative - a revival of the old EAM and a multi-party system that incorporates a broad front of leftist parties and organizations.

In the wake of the Second World War, conflict quickly arose in Greece between the partisans - a loose coalition of far-left parties, organizations, and militia groups - and the Greek government in exile and its legitimate authorities backed by the British. While the confrontation was short-lived, its scars have continued to linger on. Across the North of the country local governments, pro-government militia groups, and mobs of disgruntled citizens riled up by returning officials have been conducting campaigns targeting Leftist forces - primarily those that fought in the partisan groups, though also including even those still loyal to our regime. \n\n While this has, thus far, largely been ignored by the central government in Athens - arrests involving several of those promised amnesty, tortures, and murders have provoked an increasingly vocal and aggressive response from the Communist forces. With the world order in Europe quickly taking shape, some within the government feel the time might have come for the government to step in, if only for pragmatism's sake to stop some of the worst offenders of the continued unrest.

Across the North of Greece our comrades currently face harassment, threats, arrests, and even outright murder at the hands of rabid paramilitary organizations and local governments looking to reassert their authority over the formerly rebellious lands. While this treatment has been nothing new since Greece's liberation from Axis occupation, its likely to further fan the flames of a possible resumption of hostilities as members of the KKE and former partisan organizations turn further away from the prospects for a peaceful solution to mending the scar in Greek society.

Greece's upcoming elections are set to be some of the most important in the country's recent history. According to the agreement reached in the Treaty of Varkiza a referendum on the monarchy is set to be held later in the year, and it is likely to be heavily influenced by the ruling party at the time as well as public opinion towards the government. \n\n While currently liberal republican parties hold nominal sway over the government - their power in part carried over from the exiled administration - monarchist parties have rallied their support and stepped up their efforts to spread propaganda. There is also the matter of leftist parties in the country - legally allowed to continue their operation under the same treaty that ended the conflict. While lingering unrest and instability have cast doubts on their commitment to electoralism - they hold enough sway within the nation to potentially swing the vote with only a few months away.

Elections have come upon Greece, with each of the parties involved hoping for a victory in what is set to be a contentious and heavily partisan vote. While the ruling Liberal Party - with its republican sympathies - hopes to retain some level of power in whatever new government takes shape, monarchist parties have redoubled their effort to focus on the preservation of Greece's Kingdom. Whatever the outcome, its likely that the results will be a precursor to the planned referendum later in the year - with the ruling party likely upping its efforts to push for its own desired outcome.

As per the Treaty of Varkiza, the people are set to vote today in a referendum to decide the countries' future. The vote will determine whether Greece's monarchy will remain or whether a new republic will replace it. While thus far Greece's monarchy has survived decades of political unrest, instability, conquest, war, and occupation - it has been increasingly tested as Greece modernizes and the world around it changes. Even still, monarchist forces remain confident that the people will side with them - heavily playing to ideas of Greek patriotism and the stability they claim a monarchy can bring, hoping to counter the propaganda of left and Republican parties with their own slogans and posters.

In an unsurprising result, the referendum held today in Greece has seen the monarchy preserved. Already protests and minor scuffles have arisen - with calls that the referendum was rigged and invalid permeating the republican opposition. For our own part, the result has only emboldened our hardline supporters - solidifying the necessity for revolution and the impossibility of reform so long as the British and their client kingdom reign in Greece's affairs.

In a massive shock not only to Greece, but to the KKE as well, the referendum held today in Greece has seen the monarchy overwhelmingly voted out of its decades' long place in Greek politics. While the pro-monarchist forces already have set about protesting the result, the republicans have rejoiced together with the left - renewed hopes for a united republic shining a light into Greece's uncertain future.

Operation Torch is set to be a grand counter-offensive against the forces of the DSE - aimed primarily at striking their strongholds north of Attica. The plan, proposed in the wake of a slow retreat of communist forces, aims to put a swift end of the civil war and break the enemies' ability to continue to be on the offensive anywhere in the nation. Already preparations have been made alongside British advisors and aid, with the only thing remaining being an official government order to carry it out.

Seeking to further their efforts to aid the legitimate government of Greece, the British have sent additional aid to the country in the form of military equipment and funds. Already the generosity of the United Kingdom is being put to good use in bolstering our war effort against the communists - with outdated arms being replaced with the more advanced models provided by the British.

Spurred on by the emerging ideological conflict with the Communist World, the Americans have decided to involve themselves in the fight for control over Greece. Currently they have provided the government with some of their surplus equipment and some minor funding to help keep the army running smoothly. Already the efforts are paying off for Greece, with the unexpected help not only providing much needed supplies but a boost to morale.

Greece today has approached us with a request echoing one given from their kingdom to ours during the Second World War - permission to base themselves out of Cyprus as they flee the mainland and its surrounding islands. This comes as they lose more and more ground to the communist forces of the Democratic Army of Greece, with rebels already having taken much of the nation aside from a holdouts and popular support for the legitimate Greek government starting to wane throughout the nation. Such a request had previously been denied before on grounds that it would undermine British authority on the island - as well as the viability of basing a temporary government of exile elsewhere. This time, however, the circumstances are vastly different. \n\n Cyprus, already having proven itself a headache for the Empire with actions against our authorities on the island, once again seems to be ready to set the stage for widespread unrest in favor of its independence and desired Enosis, or union, with Greece proper. Even with such an action increasingly looking like it is an impossibility as a united nation, many advisors are bracing for the worst - with stirrings of nationalist organization already reaching the local administration. Some have suggested it might be worth accepting Greece's offer this time - even if it all but assures an end to the British presence on the island. Not only would we be spared the cost of holding onto the island, but it would keep some degree of British influence on the Greek government in exile there.

The British have accepted our proposal to rebase in Cyprus - with the colonial authorities there signaling that they are willing to cede authority and power to Greek administration as soon as the situation allows. The only thing left now is to evacuate the government and as many loyalists as we can find, a task made easier with British assistance as our brave soldiers hold the line to allow us time to flee the mainland in the face of the now inevitable fall to communism.

In a terrible turn, the British have refused our proposal to rebase in Cyprus - citing the brewing chaos on the island and the need for stability and order, as well as fears over the growing power of the Soviet Union. While they have reaffirmed they will provide shelter to any who flee the now inevitable victory of communist forces - this proves to be a massive blow to the government, and what little morale and coherence remains among the army. It seems that, for the time being, Greece is lost.

Greece has yet to recover from the dark days of occupation by the Axis forces during the Second World War, remaining a divided and broken nation on the verge of the abyss. However, the time has come to finally bring this broken and battered nation into a changing world. We have upheld all stipulations put forward by the Treaty of Varkiza that ended the bloody conflict with the communist partisans, now all that remains is to finally put to rest the last remnants of opposition to a united Greek Kingdom. We have already prepared an ultimatum to the KKE, demanding they submit to the government in Athens with the promise that their party will remain legal and its leaders free.

The Kingdom of Greece has demanded we officialize our disarmament by dissolving the remnants of our government and submitting to the authority of Athens. Such a move, given the wide-spread violations of the Treaty of Varkiza and the blatant interference from the British in the elections and referendum, is unlikely to be popular with our supporters across the nation - many of whom continue to face harassment, arrests, and even death at the hand of the monarcho-fascist tyrants. Instead, many within the KKE believe the time has finally come to prepare for a third, and final, phase to the civil war - aiming to bring liberation to Greece by force rather than by the ballot.

The KKE have refused to submit to the authority of Athens, all but affirming their intentions to once more take up arms against the state. While the police and military have already been put on high alert - its unlikely much can be done to avoid the now inevitable war for the future of the nation.

The KKE have accepted our proposal for a united Greece - joining the fold once more and agreeing to keep their activities within the legal framework for the Greek legal system and constitution. Throughout the nation people rejoice at the decision, a massive sigh of relief washing over the loyal subjects of the king as peace and stability begin to emerge from the chaos.

Since the end of the Second World War, one of the major grievances among the left wing forces within Greece has been that of the Monarchy. The communists, along with even many of the liberals, saw the institution as outdated, and oppressive - with some going so far as to point to the influence of the British in helping to prop up and preserve the power of the King. Such sentiments helped fuel a civil war in the country, and seemed to be on the path towards igniting the still smoldering kindling left in its wake. \n\n However, Greece prevailed as the people turned out and overwhelmingly voted to proclaim a republic in what will be sure to stand as one of the most important dates in Greek history. Leftist and liberal forces alike united to work towards the goal, despite their differences, and once more we must unite - though this time towards the creation of a stable and coherent Greek State. Even without the monarchy, many still have doubts - though the Treaty of Varkiza's stipulations have been followed, and the time has finally come to put an end to the division that threatens to hold the nation back.

Greece's newly proclaimed republican has come today to the KKE with an offer for unity - hoping that the leadership of the communist party will be receptive to following through on the final steps towards peace. The party themselves remains divided, even still, however. While the opportunity to work with a government no longer tainted by the British-backed monarchy has won over many within the upper leadership of the KKE, many more remain unconvinced of the sincerity of this new republic - instead preferring to continue to push for a resumption of war.

In an unfortunate turn of events, the leadership of the KKE have voted against reunification with Greece - even under the common banner of a Republic. This decision all but assures a return of conflict, and the continued division of the country as fears of bloodshed once again wash over the nation.

Greece can stand united and triumphant under the banner of Republicanism, as today the KKE has voted to accept reunification - hoping to work within the framework of a republic to achieve their dreams of a 'People's Democracy' in the nation. Celebrations across Greece have already broken out among supporters of both sides, the future secured for the moment as we work to bring Greek into the new world.

As per the Treaty of Varkiza, the people are set to vote today in a referendum to decide the countries' future. The vote will determine whether Greece's monarchy will remain or whether a new republic will replace it. While thus far Greece's monarchy has survived decades of political unrest, instability, conquest, war, and occupation - it has been increasingly tested as Greece modernizes and the world around it changes. With a coalition of left and far-left parties having swept to power in the elections, and the wave of pro-Republican propaganda that followed, little doubt surrounds the outcome of the referendum. Already initial polls show a clear majority in favor of abolishing the outdated Monarchy - plans for a new constitution already underway among members of Parliament.

With the Monarchy gone and socialists in power, there remains virtually no point for continued conflict and division between the KKE and their partisan allies and the government. Given that we are practically being given power over Greece, the leadership of the KKE - irrespective of their own differences - has nearly unanimously approved of the offer as they prepare to relocate to Athens and begin working towards building a People's Democracy.

With a nominal socialist state in the works, and the KKE having accepted the offer to rejoin the government in full, the time has come to declare an extraordinary set of elections to decide the ultimate fate of Greece.
